business.start.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Sue West) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Newman, Minister for Family and Community Services. I refer to the minister's press release announcing a top-up mechanism for people who are worse off under the new tax system. Can the minister confirm that her criteria for assessing whether someone is worse off are the `combined effects of family assistance, income tax changes, and other changes to the social security system' referred to in her press release, but not the impact of the GST, which is not mentioned? Will the minister assure the Senate that the impact of the GST will be included when deciding whether families are worse off?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Yes.

talker.name: Brownhill, Sen David
Senator BROWNHILL
talker.role: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. Minister, the government has been consistent and honest with the Australian people about the sale of Telstra. Will the minister inform the Senate of progress on this policy? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy approaches and what would be the impact if these were implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —That is a very important question from Senator Brownhill. He understands as well as all Australians, the Labor Party included, that it is very much in the interests of Australia as well as the interests of Telstra and its shareholders that we progress the sale as quickly as possible. That is a policy approach that is blindingly obvious to anyone who ever came here, to anyone who ever lived here, to anyone who ever experienced the very poor quality of service you got when the Labor Party ran Telstra, when the Labor Party never used the power of direction, when the Labor Party's policy on services was, `Well, give them a call. Ask them to come out and fix the phone. If they are too busy, I am sorry, we can't help you.' That was their approach.

answer.para: Let there be no doubt about this. We have always made it clear that we believe this is a policy in the best interests of everyone concerned—except perhaps the unions; I would have to concede that. We took that policy to the 1996 election. We took it to the 1998 election and we will take it to the next election. That will be one of the very big battle lines for the next federal election. Given that it will be one of the big battle lines drawn for the next election, tomorrow night represents a very big opportunity for the leader of the federal opposition, because my understanding is that he is going to deliver himself of a speech that will explain why Telstra should not be sold. I presume the title of the oration is `Not till we get to government'.

But what the punters will really be looking for from Mr Beazley will be not windy rhetoric or prolix prose. They just want a few home truths. They want to know why, for example, when Mr Beazley was in government he sold the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas without telling the public beforehand. In other words, he said one thing and did another, as of course he is doing now. He also should explain why he expects the public to believe him on that. It is also a very big opportunity for him to finally admit that he invited Frank Blount to come to this country so Telstra could be privatised and, at the same time, explain why he expects the public to believe him when he now denies that.

It is also a very big opportunity for Mr Beazley to explain why he was there with Paul Keating in September 1995 when they offered to sell Telstra to BHP, because all he has said so far is, `It's irrelevant whether I was there or not.' I think we all know there is a bit more to it than that. It is highly relevant. We know why he was there. It was because he was wanting to flog it to try and fix up the $10 billion budget black hole, which you on the other side all knew about but lied your heads off and said you did not. That was another classic example of Mr Beazley saying one thing and doing another. He ought to be able to explain tomorrow night why it is the Labor Party's policy to sell off Yellow Pages and MobileNet, why they only talk about core assets but are happy to divest themselves of the rest, why as Deputy Prime Minister he was happy to see Telstra sell off its networking business, IBMGSA, but now they are no longer prepared to condone that because they say it is privatisation by stealth.

There are a lot of very big issues that Mr Beazley can address tomorrow night. I think the public really wants to understand the truth, not just the smokescreen that is going to be put up between now and the next election. Explain why Cheryl Kernot was wrong when she said, `You could trust them in opposition but you certainly can't trust them in government.' (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, as I am a National Party senator representing regional people, could you tell us how the sale would allow catch-up funds for the road system, the water systems of regional Australia, the infrastructure that is badly needed out in rural Australia, and also the salinity problem that has beset the whole of the nation over the last decade, which is because of the Labor Party's absolute betrayal of the regional areas of Australia?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Senator Brownhill is dead right. You do not have to take my word for it. You can ask Carl Scully and Jim Bacon, because they have been out there saying, `Thank you very much. We like the proceeds of the sale of Telstra being applied to state infrastructure projects.' In fact, Carl Scully says, `We want a lot more of where that came from.' They are dead keen to get their hands on it—and so is the National Party and so is everyone else in rural Australia—because they recognise that the funds simply are not there otherwise. So this is another big opportunity for Mr Beazley to explain why he blocked $250 million for Networking the Nation, why he was opposed to a $670 million social bonus out of T2, why, as finance minister, he privatised everything that moved and why indeed he said, in the classic weasel words, `We won't support privatisation until there is adequate competition.' Now we have something like 40 carriers. There is going to be a lot in this speech and I look forward to being there. I will be asking the first question. So just make sure that we all have our invitations.

—My question is directed to Senator Herron in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care. Is the minister aware that the Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency has not published any inspection reports on nursing homes this year in the Northern Territory, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania? Does this mean that no review audits have been carried out in those states and territories over the last three months? Is this proof that, despite recent events, the government has taken no action this year to ensure proper standards of care in the nursing homes of the Northern Territory, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —To answer the question directly—no, it does not. The government has a very proud record of what it is doing in the aged care industry, considering what we were left with after 13 years of neglect. We inherited a destabilised aged care industry in this country. The senator knows very well that more than 14,000 places were made available for the allocation in the year 2000 approvals rounds, double the 7,000 places allocated in the 1999 round. So it is an absolute fallacy to say that we have neglected the industry. We are righting the wrongs that we inherited when the Labor Party went out of power. Thank God they went out of power. I can speak on behalf of the aged care industry itself. They left the industry in a total shambles. By their own report, there was an enormous deficit. They did not act on that report.

—Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order and it goes to relevance. I asked the minister whether or not there had been any inspections in those states and territories. It was a quite straightforward question. I hope that as a result of the point of order he can now find his brief and perhaps attempt to answer the question.
—I am sure the minister is getting to that part of the question.

—I was just winding up to give a complete answer to the question. Just because I do not respond in the manner which the opposition wants, it is not a reflection on the answer that I am about to give. The Aged Care Standards and Accreditation Agency has advised the minister that it will complete the accreditation of all aged care facilities by the legislative date of 1 January 2000. All aged care facilities were required to submit the initial application for accreditation, known as form A, by 31 December last year. All facilities have completed this part of the process. In addition, all facilities were required to complete the second stage—the self-assessment form—by 31 March 2000 to accommodate the facilities' preferences for a date of site audit. Ninety-eight per cent of all facilities have completed this process. Less than 60 are still to submit this stage of their applications. This high response illustrates the industry's acceptance of the accreditation system. Might I ask, Madam Deputy President—adopting the Melham response—what the Labor Party are going to do about the accreditation system? They are going to accept it. They are not going to change it. Just like the GST, they are not going to change it. They are not going to change our health care rebate. They are going to sit down, as my colleague Senator Vanstone said, and listen to people.

—Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The minister has now had two gos at it and has failed to answer the question about inspections. In addition to accreditation, there is a requirement for review inspections. Have you conducted any or haven't you?
—The honourable senator has got a touch of the Daryl Melhams. I have been trying—

answer.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Can I have some order so I can hear what the minister is saying and so I know whether he is talking about inspections or not?
—I am answering the question, Madam Deputy President. I am giving the process that is occurring at the moment in terms of accreditation. Following on that, I think it is essential—
—You're raving.

—I am not raving at all. Following on from my remarks about the accreditation system, the facilities that have not met the 31 March 2000 deadline are being contacted by the agency to ensure that their self-assessment form is submitted in the near future. To date the accreditation process has been completed for 424 facilities. The department is monitoring the progress of facilities towards accreditation. Contingency plans are being developed to deal with any facilities which fail to meet the accreditation deadline.

—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I again ask the minister: can you advise whether or not there have been any reports as a result of inspections on nursing homes in the Northern Territory, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania this year? They are not on the web; they are not publicly available. This seems to indicate there have been no reports. Can you or can you not confirm that there have been no review audit reports carried out in these states despite the furore about aged care?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, you will notice that the supplementary question is now more refined than the one asked previously. The previous one was just a scattergun question. Now the honourable senator is saying `this year'.
—It was in the original question.

—If it was in the original question I apologise, because I did not hear it the first time. I apologise for not hearing the question that was asked because of the row that was coming from the other side, the continual sledging and the shouting by Senator Faulkner. How is it that one can hear the question when we get this sledging from Senator Faulkner?
—Senator Herron, would you come back to the question, please.
—If there is anything that the minister has to add to the answer, I am happy to bring it back to the Senate.

—My question is to Senator Ellison representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Will the minister inform the Senate of actions the government is undertaking to consult with young people throughout Australia, particularly what outcomes the government aims to achieve from today's meeting of the National Youth Roundtable?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Payne for this very important question, because the Howard government is totally committed to communicating directly with young Australians and improving opportunities for young Australians. Today, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs formally opened the Youth Roundtable for this year. This underlines the government's commitment to that communication with young Australians. This roundtable will provide 50 participants with an excellent opportunity to communicate directly with government at a very senior level—from senior ministers to parliamentary secretaries to government officials—and they will deal with a variety of issues such as education, employment, health and wellbeing, and rural and regional affairs.

answer.para: It is a shame that we have a press release from Senator Lundy which, apart from being wrong, is totally negative in relation to this great initiative put forward by this government. Senator Lundy says that the government has prohibited the GST being an issue for discussion. In fact, this is blatantly untrue; it was raised last Sunday and continues to be a subject of discussion at this roundtable. Can I just say that Senator Lundy should be joining with the government in this important initiative. The opposition should come on board and work with the government in improving communication with young Australians and in improving opportunities for those young Australians. I note that Senator Lundy goes on to say that last year's Youth Roundtable was such a failure and that the facilitators are not participating this year. In fact, we have the lead facilitator back again, and three facilitators who worked on it last year are there today.

talk.start.para: —Everyone else quit because they couldn't stand the way it was organised.

—Why do we have such negativity from the opposition in relation to such a positive initiative for young people? We will be listening to what these young participants have to say—and I might add that we had about 1,000 applicants for this very important task. That shows the level of interest across Australia from young Australians in relation to this great initiative. This initiative will run until tomorrow and we will be listening very much to these participants, who are between the crucial ages of 15 and 24. They are the up-and-coming generation who will be running this country. I might say that one of the recommendations from last year was that this age group should participate more on boards and task forces and in initiatives put forward by the government, and we have done just that. We are involving more young Australians on government task forces and also on international and national advisory boards.

answer.para: This government is totally committed to young Australians and to advancing their cause. Some examples, apart from this National Youth Week, which I mentioned last week to the Senate are the government's youth allowance, which allows for the first time rental assistance and which encourages young people to continue their studies. That will be increased by four per cent under the new tax system. Out of 20 teenagers looking for full-time work, we have one who is currently unemployed. We have seen a reduction in youth unemployment in the March figures. This is a step in the right direction, and one which the government intends to see go further.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Aged Care. Is the minister aware that, over the last two years, hospital admissions from nursing homes increased by eight per cent while the nursing home population increased by less than one per cent over the same period? Can the minister confirm that in the 1998-99 year there were a total of 702,000 bed days spent by nursing home residents in public hospitals? Aren't these figures proof that standards of care in nursing homes are declining as a result of the government's deregulation of the sector and that more and more residents are ending up in hospital as a result?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Unlike other senators on the other side, I accept most of the statement that Senator Gibbs has made because I know she is a caring person and is knowledgeable in a number of these matters. But having said that, the facts are only half the truth; the rest is its correct interpretation. The reality is that there is an ageing population. People are getting older.
—Do you want to use that for the stolen generation as well—the facts are only half the truth?

—Even Senator Evans is getting older day by day. One day perhaps he might need the ministrations of one of these agencies. The conclusion that Senator Gibbs has drawn from those figures is not correct. What is occurring in the aged care industry is that we have set in place an accreditation agency and a registration agency. What is the Labor Party's policy? `We are going to sit down and we are going to get it right,' as Daryl Melham said. But are they going to repeal our standards and accreditation system? Not at all. No, the Labor Party has said, `We are not going to repeal what you are doing in government.' If you interpret what the Labor Party is saying, then we are doing a good deal. I would throw it back in Senator Gibbs's lap and say, `Is the Labor Party going to repeal what we have put in place to raise the standards?' Deathly silence, Madam Deputy President. Deathly silence on the other side—deathly silence. They had 13 years. Daryl Melham said they are going to fix it and they are going to do the right thing—they are going to do the right thing and fix it. The reality is that the interpretation of the figures is incorrect, or the statement that Senator Gibbs had. I know that it would have been handed to her by one of the questions committees. That is the way they work on that side. They do not allow any extemporaneous questions, as we did when we were in opposition. Why don't the backbenchers over there wake up and get some spontaneous questions rather than those raised—
—Senator Herron, would you like to address the chair and the issue, please.
—On a point of order, Madam Deputy President, I did. I was saying everything through you. I am happy for you to check the Hansard to see that that is correct.
—It is rather hard when you are turning your back—I cannot hear you very clearly.

—Madam Deputy President, another interpretation that I would put to you is that there is an ageing population. People are becoming more ill. Diabetes is going through the roof in terms of the incidence in our population. It is a reality that, with a rapidly ageing population, we are getting more people going into acute hospitals. There is no alternative to that. I am sure the Labor Party have no answer to it. We still have not heard their policy. So there is a rapidly ageing population; more people are being admitted to hospitals. One of the great things we are doing is allowing people to determine their own access to hospitals. It is a reality that there is a relatively small number in the population who are in nursing homes. It is true that the number is becoming more affected by serious disease. It is inevitable that there will be more people going into acute hospitals. So I think there are alternatives to the interpretation of the figures that Senator Gibbs has given to us, and I am happy to respond to them if she can produce concrete evidence of what she has alleged in the question.

—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Part of the question referred to the deregulation of the sector. Can the minister confirm that the increasing numbers of nursing home residents who are admitted to public hospitals are a symptom of the crisis in the government system? Aren't these figures the end result of the staff cuts and cost cutting that have occurred under your deregulated system?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —It would be very easy to answer that question with a simple no. But I do not think it warrants that. The question is alleging that we have produced chaos in the aged care system. They had 13 years to do something about it. We have been in government four years. If I may have a touch of the Daryl Melhams, we will fix it.

—My question is to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone, and is in the context of the mandatory sentencing debate. I ask the minister whether she can confirm that, despite the recent negotiation between the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Burke, and in spite of the small amount of money which will go some way towards translation services and diversionary programs, and despite tinkering at the edges of the definition of `a juvenile' in the Northern Territory, the fact remains that mandatory sentencing laws remain on the statutes in the Northern Territory and in Western Australia. I further ask the minister: given that this is the case, and given that mandatory sentencing laws are clearly a breach of our international human rights obligations, what will the Commonwealth do to address that?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for his question. Senator, I draw your attention to the information provided yesterday on the agreement reached between the Prime Minister and Mr Burke. I think, with the greatest of respect, Senator, you are being slightly polemical in referring to some changes as being `tinkering at the edges' because the joint initiative—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am sorry about the people on the other side who are only interested in stirring up this debate for their own political purposes. I understand that you have a genuine interest in this matter. The joint initiative will also deflect juveniles apprehended for minor offences from the mandatory sentencing regime by ensuring that the Northern Territory police are required to place them in a diversionary program prior to any charges being laid. Where offences are more serious, police will still be given discretion to place offenders in the same diversionary programs and, upon successful completion of those programs, not pursue charges. I regard that, Senator, as a significant move ahead.

answer.para: We all might like a magic wand whereby what we want can simply be done. Some of you may have the view that the federal system can operate with the federal parliament choosing to override the states and territories whenever it feels like it and whenever it considers it appropriate, and may have no interest in the sharing of powers between the Commonwealth and the states. We regard this as a move forward. I do not regard millions and millions of dollars as a paltry sum of money whatsoever. And at least a move forward, I would have thought, is something that somebody interested in the debate would welcome. And, maybe yes, move later for more, but don't disparage a move forward just because you want more.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her reply but I ask: is the minister aware that according to recent Australian Bureau of Statistics information the rate of indigenous imprisonment in my home state of Western Australia is some 22 times higher than that of non-indigenous people? Given that this is the case, and given that mandatory sentencing does not assist with that process, why was Western Australia so conspicuously absent from the negotiations with the Prime Minister in relation to addressing this issue, and what action will the government take to address the appalling rate of indigenous incarceration in Western Australia?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for his question. In one way I wish this was your main question because I have a storehouse of information on this that I will not be able to get to you in one minute. You are right: Western Australia, when you compare the indigenous incarceration rate—that is, so many per hundred thousand—with the non-indigenous, has the highest incarceration rate of any state. What you neglect to mention, of course, is that the Northern Territory has one of the lowest. Tasmania is the lowest; the Northern Territory is next, followed by my state and I think New South Wales and Queensland. My own state and Queensland have a rate that is double that of the Territory. What that should tell you, Senator, is that there is no good in just hanging onto mandatory sentencing and ignoring it in the Territory and in other states, and ignoring it in other offences. It should also tell you that picking on a figure such as incarceration rates does not tell you a lot, either, because the Northern Territory is almost an exemplar in that sense. The impact of the justice system on the indigenous community is a very complex issue, and it is not one that I think has been served very well by this mandatory sentencing debate. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Herron representing the Minister for Aged Care. I ask: can the minister confirm whether any of the residential aged care places announced last week have been brought forward from future allocations? Isn't it a fact that 315 of the residential aged care places that were announced last year were simply brought forward from this year's allocation? Will the minister guarantee that allocations of residential aged care places in the years 2001 and 2002 will not be reduced as a result of last week's announcement? Can the minister also confirm that the residential places that were announced last week will only in fact become operational in two to three years time?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I would have hoped that Senator Forshaw would have prefaced his question by saying, `When we left government there were 10,000 aged care places left short.' And that is a fact. There were 10,000 aged care places short, according to the Gregory report. If Senator Forshaw had prefaced his question with that comment, then I would have been happy to answer it. We were left with 10,000 aged care places short—and they are the Australian National Audit Office figures, not our figures. Even Senator Faulkner would recognise the validity of those figures.

answer.para: Madam Deputy President, 530 of the new residential places are high care residential places, and that is in accordance with the benchmark established by Labor in 1986, which Labor then failed to meet. They did not meet their own standards. This large release is in accordance with our promise to make up Labor's deficiency and provide for growth. The bulk of the new places—7,378 of them—are low care residential places. These hostel places will admit people when they first become frail. They may then age in place, as set out in the aged care legislation. This policy has provided a further 18 per cent of high care beds.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that, whilst he tried to give us a lecture in ancient history, most of which was wrong, I was asking him about announcements that were made last week. Minister, you never addressed that at all. My supplementary question is: isn't it a fact that the government has cynically inflated its recent announcement of new places as a means of providing some political cover for a minister who has no credibility? Can the minister confirm that only 291 of the 7,800 residential places announced are actually nursing home beds, the vast majority of them hostel beds for which there is less demand?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the first supplementary question is an emphatic `no'. If there is another adjective I can use, I will supplement that with `no'. I do not have an answer to the second question. I do not have a brief on that and I will have to get back to Senator Forshaw with a response from the minister.

—My question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Would the minister explain the information she gave to the Senate a moment ago that police will be required to place youngsters in diversionary programs before any charges are laid? Does this not in fact mean that the police will be putting into programs—that is, sentence—people who have not even been charged? Secondly, I ask the minister: is it the case that, under the arrangement signed yesterday by the Prime Minister, Kevin Cooke, who was recently jailed for a year for stealing a towel, Johnno, who was recently jailed for stealing textas but had quite a considerable prior record, and Jamie Warramara, jailed for a year for stealing biscuits because he was hungry on Christmas day, would all still go to jail?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —Senator, I will be happy to arrange for the people in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to give you a full briefing on diversionary programs. If you had been following the debate in relation to diversionary programs which are now used fairly widely around Australia—especially in relation to drugs—you would know that this government has worked very closely with the states to encourage diversionary programs in relation to first-time offenders and drugs. The program generally works like this: when the police believe they have apprehended the appropriate person who has committed an offence, the person is given a choice—`Would you like to go on a diversionary program and hopefully find a better way?' or `Would you like to be charged with the offence?' Those people who do not choose to go into the diversionary program, or who go into it and then drop out, still face the option of charges. That is how a diversionary program works. It is a choice between proceeding into the criminal justice system, and the consequences that follow, or offering what we believe is a better alternative. We are doing this in relation to drugs, the states are doing it in relation to a whole variety of other offences, and there is an agreement to do it in relation to offenders in the Northern Territory. I would have thought that would have been understood.

—Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Firstly, does the minister therefore equate youngsters stealing biscuits because they are hungry with a need for the same remedial treatment that applies to drug addicts in the Northern Territory and Western Australia? Is that the level of thinking behind this deal? Secondly, will the minister answer the question about the three specific people, the celebrated cases—that is, Kevin Cooke, who stole a towel; Johnno, who stole textas; and Jamie, who stole biscuits. Would they still not go to jail under the minister's arrangement?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —Senator, you ask, `Does this mean you equate people who might be charged with these offences—juveniles in the Territory—with drug addicts? I remind you that the diversionary programs in relation to drugs are focused on first-time offenders, who are not necessarily addicts. The whole purpose of a diversionary program is to try to stop someone falling into that trap. So I suppose the short answer to that question is `no'.

answer.para: You invited me to comment on a couple of phrases that you snatched out of somewhere, attached to people's names, and you referred to them as celebrated cases. As someone behind you once properly said, you are a camera chaser. If you think I am going to comment on individual cases with some little catchphrase that you have dragged out of thin air, you are mistaken. The criminal justice system and its impact on the indigenous community is not served by that kind of cheap debate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question to Senator Hill relates to the agreement between the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. Will the minister clarify who will be responsible for monitoring the effectiveness and the fair operation of the initiatives to do with mandatory sentencing, announced by the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory yesterday? Does the minister agree that it would not be appropriate for the Northern Territory government to be given this responsibility? Changes are to be carried out by way of alterations to the general orders of the Northern Territory Police. The minister might want to check, but can he tell the Senate whether those general orders are public documents and freely available, or are they comparable to the general orders of the Victorian police, as I knew them in the 1960s, which were confidential and which were in the brown bomber(Time expired)

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I want to have this answer checked, but I assume it is to be administered by the Northern Territory government. That is what we would expect. They are responsible for law and order in the Northern Territory. We have sought to assist the Northern Territory government by providing further options in relation to diversionary opportunities and to help with the funding of those options. In particular, as the honourable senator will know, there is another $5 million per annum to fund new programs for juveniles, and we will jointly fund an Aboriginal interpreter service and matters of that nature. But the administration should primarily be the responsibility of the Northern Territory. I think it is fair to say that in this instance the Northern Territory government will be watched carefully not only by the Commonwealth but by all Australians to see that the arrangement that has been agreed by the Northern Territory Chief Minister is fully implemented to the letter and in spirit as well.

answer.para: The purpose of this agreement is to ensure that young offenders have a better opportunity to avoid detention and hopefully this will constructively put them on the path for a life that will not involve criminal activity. That is our objective. We want to see not only that our funding is properly spent in that regard but also that it proves to be successful in that objective. I will check whether or not the orders are made public. I suspect in this instance they would be made public for the purpose of giving public confidence in the process. I will follow that up.

talk.start.para: —Madam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. As the situation now exists, you have a judicial review of the way in which a young person is dealt with through the courts. Since this is an alternative, will there be any basis for a judicial review of what the police decide? —My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill. Will the minister inform the Senate as to how the Howard government is protecting Kakadu National Park, and can he tell the Senate what steps are being taken to improve the living conditions and employment opportunities of the park's traditional owners?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable senator for that important question, because we have just been celebrating the 21st anniversary of the declaration of stage 1 of Kakadu National Park, which I remind the Senate was another outstanding environmental achievement of the former Fraser government. It was an anniversary marked with some sadness due to the recent death of one of the senior traditional owners. He was a man who had a deep commitment to his traditional lands and a vision for the advancement of the indigenous people of the region. But the anniversary gave us the opportunity to reflect on the successes of Kakadu National Park.

answer.para: The world heritage values of the park continue to be managed and protected under a joint agreement between the Commonwealth and the traditional owners. This is despite the increasingly dishonest claims of groups such as the Australian Conservation Foundation. Last week they were at it again, trying to scare everyone about a potential water spill from a retention pond at the Jabiluka mine site. For the record, the independent Supervising Scientist has advised that there is no imminent risk of overflow or release. He also advises that no approvals have been given for discharge of excess run-off waters and that none will occur this wet season. His advice also repudiates claims that the pond was constructed without the necessary approvals.

I am able to report to the Senate even more progress in the protection of Kakadu. In July last year, the Howard government committed almost $3.2 million to upgrading tourism infrastructure in the park. Planning or construction is already under way on key projects such as the Yellow Water boardwalk, the Jim Jim Falls road, the Jim Jim Falls camp ground and new boardwalks. These projects are important in presenting the national values of the park in a way that also protects them from damage. They will help attract more tourists to the region, providing jobs and other economic benefits to the local population. We are also well advanced in implementing our response to the Kakadu Regional Social Impact Study, under the leadership of former Labor Senator Bob Collins. This includes: new housing, construction and major upgrades worth $1.2 million, which are under way in a number of Kakadu out-stations; $3 million worth of construction, due to begin on improvements to basic infrastructure such as power, sewerage and water reticulation; and better employment opportunities through community development employment projects and through Parks Australia, which has increased its numbers of indigenous trainee park rangers.

We have launched a groundbreaking hospitality training course for indigenous people, based in the Crocodile Hotel. Already 22 young Aboriginal people are in training, and there are more to follow. We are giving them the skills to help them take advantage of the growing tourism and hospitality industry in the Northern Territory—real training for real jobs. We are negotiating with the Northern Territory government to co-fund a new Aboriginal education unit at the Jabiru Area School to provide increased levels of education to young Aboriginal people in an environment that respects their cultural background. And we are working on a number of measures to improve the delivery of health services throughout the region. I have sought to demonstrate to the Senate that not only are we proud of proclaiming the first stage of the park but also, in celebrating its 21st anniversary, we are working on practical and sensible ways to work with the local indigenous people to give them jobs for the future, better health, better education and better homes.
Madam Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE

Senator HILL
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill) and the Minister for Justice and Customs (Senator Vanstone), to questions without notice asked today, relating to mandatory sentencing.

speech.para: There are some real worries about the arrangements that were made between the Chief Minister and the Prime Minister, altering the way the criminal justice system is carried out in the Northern Territory. The changes to the way the criminal justice system is being carried out in the Northern Territory are not to be made by parliament, are not to be made by way of regulation, are not to be made—as far as I understand—by any instrument that is reviewable before this parliament or any other; the changes are to be made to the general orders under which the Northern Territory police operate. It has been said—Senator Vanstone said it before—that parliament can limit judicial functions. In fact, there is a bill in the area of migration law that is going to do that, but at least parliament has a say. In this agreement, where there is a change to be made to the general criminal justice system, parliament is to have no say at all because what is going to be changed to effect the new system is the general orders of the Northern Territory police.

I do not know whether those documents are public and freely available. Senator Hill did not know whether those documents are public and freely available. Did the Prime Minister know whether those documents are public and freely available when he made the arrangements with the Chief Minister? If those documents are not public and freely available, how are we going to judge whether the police are carrying out their duties under the criminal justice system in the way they ought to be carried out? How are they going to be checked? I would have thought that that was one thing which should have been known right from the start. It is said in the joint statement by the Prime Minister, the Hon. John Howard MP, and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, the Hon. Denis Burke MLA, that:

quote.para: They agreed that their common objective was to prevent juveniles entering the criminal justice system.

speech.para: They go on to talk about a scheme which is to be set up under the general orders of the Northern Territory police. If the police come in and examine a person accused of an offence, then that person has entered the criminal justice system there and then because the police are part of the criminal justice system. So for this statement to say that there is an agreement that their common objective is to prevent juveniles entering the criminal justice system is just not to the point. It is not correct because the rest of the document talks about a changed criminal justice system.

talk.start.para: —You are talking about it in terms of post prosecution. This is a pre-prosecution intervention.

—Exactly. Senator Hill has explained it by saying that what this means is that we are going to cut out the judicial part of the criminal justice system. That is the part which makes the criminal justice system patent to the public, so that we understand what is going to go on. That is going to be crossed out.
—What?
—The other thing that is going to happen under this—
—No-one is going to complain about not being prosecuted.

—People might not complain about not being prosecuted, but a lot of other people might complain about them not being prosecuted. In other words, the victims have a bit of a say in this. You have always been for the victim. In this case there is no consideration given to the victim; it is up to the police. They are going to exercise a discretion which is a larger discretion than any other police force in this country has. It is a matter of having things done by the executive rather than having things done by the judiciary. It is another attack by this government, unfortunately, on the judicial system of this country—whether it is in this area, whether it is in the area of migration or anywhere else. This is a further attack, carried out through the general orders of the Northern Territory police, on the judiciary. (Time expired)

talker.name: Abetz, Sen Eric
Senator ABETZ
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The speech by Senator Cooney shows once again how the Labor Party seem to be more concerned about process than outcomes. Surely, I would have thought, the Labor Party would have celebrated the wonderful outcome that was achieved as a result of negotiation between two heads of government within this country. It was an outcome that I thought, in fact, Senator Cooney and his party were wanting to achieve. But, of course, as is so often the wont with the Australian Labor Party at the moment, they are in a position of policy paralysis and they do not know what they want.

speech.para: In fact, in Senator Cooney's contribution we were not told what Labor would have done if it had been in power. But just in case the Australian people want to have some indication of what Labor would have done if it were in power and Kim Beazley were to have been Prime Minister, listen to this. On 16 February this year, Mr Beazley said, `I think mandatory sentencing has to go.' It was black and white. Six days later he said, `I agree'—see, he is softening now—`that it is more desirable that it be done at the level of government that actually enforced the laws.' Then, on 31 March, he said, `The criminal law of Western Australia should be determined by West Australians, and there's no question about that.' So within a month we had the double backflip. First of all he was saying mandatory sentencing had to go and then, within the course of a month, he was saying, `Well, really, Western Australia can determine it for itself.'

On this occasion, in a very sophisticated move, the Prime Minister was able to talk to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and achieve an outcome that I thought virtually everybody in this parliament wanted—that is, a softening of the Territory's approach. Let me simply remind Senator Cooney and honourable senators opposite that if they really do want judicial discretion, let us look at the outcomes in those jurisdictions that do have judicial discretion and no mandatory penalties. What do you find in relation to the incarceration rate of our indigenous population? The Northern Territory, with its mandatory sentencing policy, had the second lowest rate of Aboriginal incarceration per 100,000 of population—lower than any other state or territory bar Tasmania. My home state of Tasmania had an even lower rate than the Northern Territory. So those who would celebrate judicial discretion are in fact celebrating a higher rate of incarceration of our indigenous population. They are the facts and figures, and it is unfortunate that certain friends of ours within the media, and the public commentators, do not grasp the facts and do not grasp the figures but just run with platitudes that sound warm and caring.

The fact is—and I repeat—the jurisdictions with judicial discretion in this country had a higher rate of indigenous incarceration per 100,000 head of population than the Northern Territory. Once again, it is a classic example of Senator Cooney and the Labor Party saying, `We want judicial discretion no matter what the impact will be on the indigenous community.' That is really what they are saying. Then Senator Cooney and the Labor Party—and I assume he is speaking on behalfof the Labor Party—bemoan the fact that judges will not have a say in relation to the diversionary therapy proposals. Let me simply say to Senator Cooney: we would try to catch the young offender and save him or her from the judicial system altogether. I would have thought that was humane, I would have thought that was responsible and I would have thought that was a good social outcome if you had a genuine social conscience and a genuine social concern rather than a simple concern for cheap headlines, irrespective of the social outcomes. We on this side are very proud of the agreement that the Prime Minister was able to reach with the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. Other Labor speakers might like to tell us what they would have actually done if they were in government, other than engage in a cheap discourse of political point scoring which, of course, is not aided by the facts because the facts speak against exactly what Senator Cooney was trying to put to us.

talk.start.para: —I also want to speak on this taking note of the responses to a number of questions during today's question time. Let us, in the first instance, deal with the reaction of the Northern Territory to yesterday's agreement. The Chief Minister of the Northern Territory was on television and all of the electronic media last evening claiming a big win—a win-win—because he achieved everything he set out to achieve during the negotiations on this, and pocketed $5 million to boot. That is $5 million a year. But his legislation remains intact, apart from one very significant and, I might say, very welcome amendment to it—that is, that the age of juveniles will move from 17 to 18. That is welcomed by us. But the agreement of yesterday actually brings more concern than it does joy, despite the joy that we feel about the movement in age from 17 to 18.

speech.para: A major part of those concerns has already been addressed by my colleague Senator Cooney in dealing with the enhanced and increased powers that are given to the police force in the Northern Territory by yesterday's agreement. There is no question at all that the police have been given enhanced and increased responsibility under the agreement of yesterday. I do not know if they will be given any additional resources. The bigger questions that Senator Cooney addressed are: what is the public accountability of those increased powers to the police forces and where is that going to be seen? We have not yet seen the small print of this agreement. Of course, there are things in this agreement that we welcome, but they are only a step—and, let's face it, a step in the right direction. The right direction will be the removal of mandatory sentencing laws from the statute books not only of the Northern Territory but also of my home state, Western Australia. It is a very blunt instrument to be using in the law enforcement area, and it has been proved on a number of occasions that mandatory sentencing is just not working.

There are people who are very happy about the agreement, particularly backbenchers on the government side, and they are saying that no longer would juveniles be incarcerated for minor offences. The detail of that is not contained in yesterday's announcement. The detail is that the police have got certain powers to direct persons—young offenders—onto the diversionary programs if they so decide. Is it going to be compulsory or mandatory that the individuals be so diverted? If it is, will it mean that a 17-year-old can go on a rampage and end up on a diversionary program while an 18-year-old accompanying them will be automatically charged—because the police have no discretion over whether to charge or not to charge—and as a consequence will be faced with mandatory sentencing? It is a much more severe regime for adults than for juveniles in the Northern Territory.

That is not to say that we do not welcome the change in age, but the announcement yesterday does beg a whole host of questions, which are heightened when one looks back at the Senate committee's investigation and the questions that were asked of the representatives of the Northern Territory government about what was happening in the Northern Territory at the time. We wanted to know the number of young offenders who had been convicted and sentenced under the mandatory sentencing regime. After a matter of months we got some information but, even to this day, the public of the Northern Territory, this Senate, the parliament and the public of Australia do not know the number of offenders who were charged at 16 and sentenced as adults at 17 in the Northern Territory. That information is not yet available, and there is no public accountability contained in the joint announcement made yesterday by the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. Yet we are going to hand over $5 million a year—which is welcome—for the diversionary programs. The increased funding for the interpreter service is also welcome; it is a much needed thing that has not previously been in existence. We have had scenarios where individuals who did not understand English were being charged through the courts of the Northern Territory, convicted in the courts of the Northern Territory and sentenced under the mandatory sentencing regime when they did not understand what was happening. The minister simply stated in response that `UNFPA has included providing laundry equipment to the maternity clinic at Pristina'. I think it was three washing machines or something like that. talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the further answer given by the Minister for Justice and Customs (Senator Vanstone), to a question without notice asked by Senator Greig today, relating to mandatory sentencing.

speech.para: In doing so, I want to express my very real disappointment that I seemingly cannot get a straight answer to a straight question on this issue. I am referring specifically to the first and key part of my question asked here today which was that, in spite of the conciliation and negotiation between the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory and our Prime Minister that resulted in a deal which we learned of yesterday, mandatory sentencing remains. I touched on that deal briefly. It in part included some $5 million of additional funding to the Northern Territory to assist with diversionary programs, in addition to which the definition of `juvenile' was slightly tinkered with so that 17-year-olds were no longer vulnerable as they previously were and the definition of an adult is now 18 years. I do welcome that. In terms of the $5 million funding, I maintain my argument that that is really a paltry amount of funding for the substantial difficulties and problems that are faced by many people in the Northern Territory in relation to the criminal laws, most particularly indigenous Northern Territorians.

I note also that a part of the package has resulted in an interpreter service being provided. I welcome that also but I feel a sense of shame, to be frank, that this was not there in the first instance. As has been noted in this chamber previously, if you happen to be an illegal immigrant landing on our shores then you are provided with an interpreter service in order to process the legalities that you would need to go through in terms of immigration or refugee status. Yet, if you are a first Australian and a juvenile offender in the Northern Territory, you had no right to that until recently. Again, I welcome this particular outcome of the negotiation but feel quite appalled that it was not there in the first instance. I acknowledge also that there will be more money available to diversionary programs, and that too is a good thing. But at the core of my question was simply this: in spite of all that, is it not the fact that mandatory sentencing laws still exist in the Northern Territory and Western Australia? From recollection, I do not think the minister answered that or answered that clearly.

That is at the core of my question because we either accept that mandatory sentencing per se is acceptable or it is not. The Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, of which I am a member, found in its inquiry and deliberations that mandatory sentencing laws clearly breach international treaties, most significantly in relation to CROC, the Convention on the Rights of the Child. It would appear that they would also be in contravention of CERD, the treaty relating to racial discrimination. I think we as a nation have to take such treaties very seriously. You can argue strongly that we did that in terms of speaking with state and territory governments prior to signing on to these treaties. As a nation, we have signed on to these basic benchmarks of human rights and dignity. Yet it is quite clear that the government is not serious in adhering to those, even when we have the most flagrant breaches, and this has most recently flared up in the Northern Territory. A joint press release issued yesterday between the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Denis Burke, and Prime Minister John Howard stated, in part, in paragraph 6:

quote.para: The Northern Territory legislation will be amended so that a person will be treated as an adult from 18 years of age rather than at 17 years of age. Apart from this, the mandatory sentencing provisions of the existing law will remain unchanged.

speech.para: This begs the question: why bother? Why bother going to all this trouble to get additional funding for interpreter services, a special juvenile court and diversionary programs and why bother tinkering with the definition of `juveniles' and finding innovative ways of getting around this law, when it would have been far simpler, far more intelligent and more comprehensive, if we are to include Western Australia—and I think we must—to have simply repealed these laws in the first place rather than messing around with them at the edges? I am not alone in that view.

I note also that, following the announcement of the Prime Minister yesterday, the Law Council of Australia strongly criticised that, arguing that this was `simply political window dressing which, on the face of it, vests more power in the Territory's police force'. That was said by Dr Gordon Hughes, the Law Council spokesperson. The real remedy, he said, would have been to abolish mandatory sentencing and to restore judicial discretion to judicial officers in sentencing matters. I can only agree. The outstanding question to the minister is: do mandatory sentencing laws breach our international treaty obligations or do they not?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

quote.para: The Jurisdiction of Courts Legislation Amendment Bill has been necessitated by recent decisions of the High Court.

The Bill responds to the High Court's decision last year in the Re Wakim case, which invalidated the `cross-vesting' of State jurisdiction on federal courts; and to the Court's decision this year in the Bond case, which identified problems in relation to the powers of the Commonwealth DPP.
It also precludes delaying tactics in the criminal justice process by reducing the `collateral' access of defendants to federal administrative law procedures and remedies.
The general cross-vesting scheme was established in 1987 by the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-Vesting) Act 1987, and by reciprocal legislation in the States and Territories.

The purpose of the legislation was to establish a system of cross-vesting of jurisdiction between federal, State and Territory superior courts to overcome uncertainties that exist as to the jurisdictional limits of those courts.

Under this system, a litigant could, broadly speaking, institute proceedings in a superior court anywhere in Australia without regard to jurisdictional limits, subject only to the possibility that the proceedings would be transferred to a more appropriate court.
The system was welcomed as the answer to arid and inconvenient jurisdictional debates which had plagued litigants, practitioners and courts.
A separate cross-vesting scheme was subsequently established for matters arising under the Corporations Law.

The High Court decided in June last year, however, that the conferral of State jurisdiction on the Federal and Family Courts under the general and corporations law cross-vesting arrangements is not permitted by the Constitution.
The decision, which is known as Re Wakim, was regrettable.

In undermining the cross-vesting arrangements which I have mentioned, and a number of other co-operative arrangements, it undermined arrangements which have permitted a significant growth in national co-operation between the States, and between the States and the Commonwealth.
Re Wakim has had a particularly negative effect in relation to the Corporations Law scheme, significantly reducing the Federal Court's involvement.
The special cross-vesting arrangements were regarded as a fundamental element of the fully integrated system of State, Territory and federal adjudication contemplated by the Corporations Agreement.

The explanatory memorandum for the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 - which introduced the special cross-vesting arrangements - confirmed that they were intended `to enhance the national character of the new scheme'.
The cross-vesting arrangements were regarded as `central to the conferral of a national character' on the corporations law scheme.
The Commonwealth Parliament cannot restore all of the elements of the cross-vesting arrangements which were affected by Re Wakim.
It lacks constitutional power to do so.

In recognition of this constitutional fact, the States have all enacted legislation, the Federal Courts (State Jurisdiction) Acts, which give effect to past ineffective decisions of federal courts as if they had been made by State courts.
The State legislation also provides for proceedings invalidly commenced in federal courts to be transferred to State courts.
Co-operative measures are also being explored.
An appropriate referral of power by the States to the Commonwealth under subsection 51(xxxvii) of the Constitution would address the loss of the Federal Court's Corporations Law jurisdiction.

A fully integrated national corporations law scheme, reflecting the existing co-operative approach to regulation and amendment, could be established by the Commonwealth if the State parliaments were prepared to refer the necessary power.
To this end, Commonwealth officers have begun work on a proposal for a suitable referral.
A detailed proposal will be developed in consultation with the States and Territories for consideration by Commonwealth, State and Territory ministers.

para.inline: SCHEDULES 1, 3 AND 4 TO THE BILL: RESPONSE TO RE WAKIM

quote.para: The Commonwealth can take more immediate steps to address some of the problems created by Re Wakim.
That is what this Bill does.
The first and most obvious step is to repeal the now invalid provisions of Commonwealth laws that purport to consent to the conferral of State jurisdiction on federal courts.
This is done in Schedule 1 to the Bill.

The Commonwealth Parliament may also take steps to confer jurisdiction on any court to review decisions made by Commonwealth officers, whether in the exercise of powers conferred by State or Commonwealth laws.
The Commonwealth can thus ensure that the Federal Court continues to play an important part in the co-operative arrangements already mentioned.
Commonwealth officers and authorities are invested with powers by State law under various co-operative arrangements.
Indeed, this has been a common feature of the co-operative federalism that has evolved over recent years.
Under the Corporations Law, for example, the Australian Securities and Investment Commission, a Commonwealth authority, is invested with powers and functions by States.
The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is also invested with powers and functions by States under State Competition Policy Reform Acts and State Price Exploitation Codes.

Since the establishment of the Federal Court, it has been accepted that the Federal Court, rather than State courts or tribunals, generally should have the function of reviewing the actions and decisions of Commonwealth officers and authorities.
I shall discuss what is perhaps the only significant exception to this general policy later, in relation to Schedule 2 and criminal prosecutions in State or Territory courts.
Accordingly, where States conferred jurisdiction on Commonwealth officers and authorities under various co-operative schemes, federal courts were given jurisdiction.
The policy was clear.
The Commonwealth administrative law regime should apply to the actions and decisions of Commonwealth officers and authorities.
Federal courts and tribunals should review the actions and decisions of Commonwealth officers and authorities.
The means chosen before Re Wakim to give effect to this policy was for the States to adopt as State law relevant Commonwealth administrative laws.

The particular laws adopted varied in each case, but would involve one or all of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975, the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Privacy Act 1988 or the Ombudsman Act 1976.
The Federal Court was then invested with State jurisdiction to hear matters under this applied legislation.
However, the decision in Re Wakim meant that this approach no longer works.
In so far as the adoption of Commonwealth administrative laws by States also involves conferral of State jurisdiction on the Federal Court, it is invalid.
Schedule 1 to the Bill resolves this problem.
It amends the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.
The amendments bring the decisions and actions of Commonwealth officers and authorities under certain States laws within the scope of these Commonwealth Acts.
The Federal Court, when exercising jurisdiction in relation to these decisions and actions, will be exercising federal jurisdiction, not State jurisdiction.
This means that the Federal Court will continue to fulfil its role as the primary forum for review of the actions and decisions of Commonwealth officers and authorities.
State and Territory Supreme Courts will be given equivalent federal jurisdiction in limited circumstances.

This limited jurisdiction is intended simply to avoid `splitting' judicial review proceedings and substantive proceedings between federal and State and Territory courts where the substantive proceedings must be brought in the State or Territory court.

I note in passing that, while Re Wakim invalidated the conferral of State jurisdiction on federal courts, it did not invalidate the conferral by Commonwealth law of Territory jurisdiction on those courts.
The Bill, however, treats Territories in the same way as States, in order to achieve uniform federal coverage of matters under State and Territory laws.
It has already been noted that the Territories were consulted in developing this approach, and had no objections.
Schedules 3 and 4 also address consequences of Re Wakim.

Following Re Wakim, an unintended consequence of amendments of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act 1989 made by the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Act 1999 is that actions for misleading or deceptive conduct in relation to securities can no longer be brought in the Federal Court.
Schedule 3 will reinstate the Federal Court's jurisdiction under the Australian Securities and Investments Commission Act by reference to the new Corporations Law actions.
The Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Act also inserted s.659B in the Corporations Law.

It was designed to ensure that the Corporations and Securities Panel would be the primary forum for resolving takeover disputes under the Corporations Law, in order to allow such disputes to be resolved as quickly and efficiently as possible by a specialist body largely comprised of takeover experts.

Section 659B was designed to prevent legal proceedings in relation to a takeover bid, including judicial review of Panel decisions under any State administrative laws, before the end of the bid period.
Only proceedings commenced on the application of ASIC, or another public authority of the Commonwealth or a State, were to be exempted.
Schedule 4 is necessary given other amendments in this Bill to give effect to the original policy behind section 659B.
Proposed section 59A of the Corporations Act will give section 659B of the Corporations Law additional force under the Corporations Act as a Commonwealth law applying to the Federal Court.
Schedule 5 will amend the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983 to deal with technical deficiencies in Commonwealth legislation identified in the High Court's recent decision in the Bond case.
Schedule 5 will amend the Act in three ways.

It will authorise the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, or a member of the Director's staff, to exercise rights of appeal conferred under State or Territory law in relation to prosecutions for State or Territory offences.
It will put beyond doubt the Director's rights of appeal in relation to proceedings for summary conviction in respect of Commonwealth offences.
And it will put beyond doubt the Director's authority to carry on or respond to appeals instituted by others in relation to such proceedings.
The amendments will thus restore what had been thought to be the situation before the decision in the Bond case.

In that decision, the High Court held that a staff member of the Office of the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions did not have the power to appeal a sentence imposed by the Supreme Court of Western Australia on Mr Alan Bond for breaches of the Western Australian Companies Code.

In particular, the amendments will allow a role under Commonwealth law for the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, and the Office of the Director, in relation to prosecutions and appeals under the Companies Code considered in the Bond case.
However, it will be necessary for the States and Territories to consider their own laws in the light of the amendments of Commonwealth legislation made by this Bill.

The Attorney-General shall be writing to the States and Territories to bring them up to date with the Commonwealth amendments, and to ask them to confirm that their own laws are adequate to give the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions the role that was intended under co-operative arrangements.

para.inline: SCHEDULE 2 TO THE BILL: REVIEW OF DECISIONS IN CRIMINAL PROCESS

quote.para: Schedule 2 to the Bill deals with judicial review of decisions in federal, State and Territory courts, but in the specific context of criminal prosecution.

The object is to avoid the use of unmeritorious delaying tactics in the criminal justice process, by removing the `collateral' access of defendants to federal administrative law procedures and remedies.

Schedule 2 contains amendments of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, the Corporations Act 1989 and the Judiciary Act 1903 that will, in federal criminal matters, restrict defendants' access to administrative law remedies.
Defendants will not be able to use the ADJR Act to challenge decisions to prosecute.
Nor will they be able to use that Act to challenge other decisions in the criminal justice process after a prosecution or appeal has commenced.

Further, defendants in State and Territory courts will not be able to rely on section 39B of the Judiciary Act to bring an application in the Federal Court to review decisions of Commonwealth officers made in the prosecution process.
The 39B jurisdiction will in that case be removed from the Federal Court and conferred on State and Territory Supreme Courts.
Section 39B of the Judiciary Act is currently a provision of general application which allows Federal Court action for mandamus, prohibition or an injunction against an officer of the Commonwealth.
This same jurisdiction is constitutionally entrenched as part of the High Court's original jurisdiction under subsection 75(v) of the Constitution.

If the 39B jurisdiction in relation to prosecutions in State and Territory courts were not removed from the Federal Court, and conferred instead on State and Territory Supreme Courts, the opportunity to disrupt and delay those prosecutions by repeated, unmeritorious applications to a different court system - in this case the Federal Court system - would remain.
The expectation is that there will be significant advantage in requiring all decisions relating to the criminal justice process to be made in the system in which the prosecution is brought.

Without reducing fairness or access to justice, the expectation is that the transfer of jurisdiction will contribute to increased efficiency, and reduction in costly delays which may otherwise result from access to two court systems.
The Commonwealth cannot legislate to restore all of the elements of the co-operative arrangements rendered invalid by the decision in Re Wakim.
But it has taken positive steps in the Bill to reinstate federal court jurisdiction lost as a result of that decision
Further, the Bill will restore what had been thought to be the situation of the Commonwealth DPP under co-operative arrangements before the decision in the Bond case.
