talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I would like to save time by putting on the record why the government is not prepared to accept these amendments. I think any thinking person would have to agree that it is not a good way to go. I remind the committee that parliament passed legislation introducing the 10 per cent threshold for the sharing of the family tax benefit in June last year, and there was unanimous support.

speech.para: We are in the process of sending an information package to 2.3 million families. I do not have a copy of it with me now, but I can assure you that it is printed and it is on its way out to people. Over one million families have already received this package. The mail-out to families is based on the legislation that was passed by this Senate unanimously last year, and it is telling families about a whole range of matters, including shared care. The families are requested to complete and return a claim form based on the information that is in the package. Information in the package includes comprehensive details about the shared care arrangements that were passed, as I said, in June last year.

The ALP's proposed amendments would move the sharing threshold to 30 per cent and allow sharing of payment at a lower level on application, but only with the agreement of both separated parents. It is superficially attractive. I recognise that, on the face of it, it seems quite a reasonable thing to try. But it is not, and the sad thing is that the amendments would result in up to 5,500 losers among parents with less than 30 per cent care who are already receiving family allowance. So it is really a serious matter. The parliament passed legislation, Centrelink sent out an information package to parents, and one million families have already received the package. They are being asked to fill in their details and send them back to Centrelink, but there will be 5,500 losers among parents who are already getting family allowance.

The proposed amendments would give power to one parent, and to me this is one of the most serious things about it. The administrative things are important, of course, the confusion for parents is important, and the losers are important, but this would give power to one parent in an area of great emotion—as we were saying yesterday when we were debating changes to the child support legislation. When parents have separated they want their children properly supported, they want to have time with them, and they want to be a real parent to them. This is an area which is fraught with emotion already, but the ALP amendments would give veto power to one parent. If that parent has between 70 per cent and 90 per cent of care, they could determine the financial circumstances of their former partner, who has up to 30 per cent care of the child. Is that reasonable? In a perfect world, everybody would be gracious. There has never been this requirement before, and it is not the requirement now. This is now administered in an impartial way by Centrelink. There is no ability by one parent to veto the arrangements for the other parent, and I would have thought that the ALP would have realised that this would be the impact. I am sure they would not have agreed to it if they had known. As the payment could be shared only by agreement of both separated parents, the proposed amendment would create an environment of dispute between the parents that is not in the current system. There are disputes enough, and the current system does not give an opportunity for a further dispute in this area.

If you are going to ensure fairness, it is essential that a parent's entitlement to family assistance be determined by the Family Assistance Office, not at the discretion of a former partner. The amendment would put at risk the entitlements of parents. Let us not forget that these are parents who are making the effort to have substantial, ongoing care arrangements for their child or children, such as every weekend or every second weekend plus half the school holidays. We are all very sad if children lose the benefit of the second parent in their lives, but where a parent is really trying to make the effort to maintain meaningful contact with the children who are with their former spouse, that parent is trying to do the right thing by their kids. Sharing the care by having the children every weekend or every second weekend and half the school holidays is a pretty typical arrangement between families who do not have insurmountable relationship problems which keep them from doing the best thing by their children.

Any change now would jeopardise the proper implementation of the legislation. It would result in increased administrative costs to alter work that is already well under way. It would also increase the ongoing cost of administration. The initial estimates that have been provided to me by my department are that the cost would be $23.7 million in 2000-01 and $21 million in subsequent years. Ten per cent, as is in their legislation, is a reasonable test of material care, recognising of course that parents with this level of care do incur significant costs in caring for their children. But, whatever the level, we should surely be encouraging it.

Recent Australian research does show that parents with this level of care or more incur relatively significant costs due to the need to provide a bedroom, furnishings, food, clothes, health care and entertainment. The 1996 family law reforms were introduced with the intention of promoting the parenting role of both parents and their continuing role in the lives of their children following separation. Surely this Senate will not lightly walk away from that commitment to children, to the parents who love them and to the parents who are trying to do the right thing by them. Surely, having agreed to a legislative arrangement last June, we will not at the eleventh hour send everything into confusion, produce 5,500 losers and damage the relationship between the two spouses who are trying to have an agreement that works for their children.

talk.start.para: —The minister's comments about damaging relationships, et cetera, are unfortunate. I think that sets the wrong tone. I want her to answer this question: what will the government do with situations now? Will you automatically split the payment 90-10? What happens to families who have other arrangements? Will it be that automatically you will split the payment between the two parents? Say a mother who is a custodial parent is receiving 100 per cent now: will the effect of this measure be that they will automatically go to 90-10, whether they make application or not?
—The answer to that is yes.

—Therefore, Minister, you will be able to detail the number of losers under that proposal—the number of people who will actually lose family benefit automatically as a result of this measure? As you were able to tell us the 5,000, you will be able to tell us how many of the people who get 100 per cent now will get less as a result of this measure. How many is that?
—You said you lose benefit. They are not losing benefit.
—If they get 100 per cent now, and they get 90 per cent tomorrow, don't they lose benefit?
—They are losing a percentage. They are not losing the benefit, which is what you said. I think you want to be very accurate on this.

—Minister, I do not want to be patronised. I asked you the question, and it seems it is a sensible question. You can have a semantics debate if you like. You talk about losers, but you only use the losers that you want to use to advance your argument. You have just admitted that, under your provision, parents who are currently getting 100 per cent benefit will receive 90 per cent of the benefit. So they will lose 10 per cent of the benefit. How many of those are in the system? How many people will have their benefits reduced by 10 per cent as a result of this measure?

—There is a difference, Senator Evans. First of all, if I am courteous to you, I do not think it is reasonable for you to suggest that I am patronising you. I treat you as a civilised individual, as I believe you to be.
—You are patronising me.
—I am afraid that that is a defence mechanism on your part; it is not intended.
—Everyone thinks you patronise them.
—Some of your colleagues I wouldn't even be terribly courteous to, but I am to you.
—Don't patronise me; just answer the question.
—I will answer it too. I'll give you both: 5½ thousand people will lose benefits. That is different from whatever the number of people is who will lose some benefit.

—Minister, you have come into this chamber, and you have information that supports your case. We admit this is a balancing argument. We have asked you a reasonable question: how many people will lose benefits as a result of your cutting the benefit from 100 per cent of the rate to 90 per cent of the rate?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The issue is a bit complicated because there are a number of people who do not currently claim the 10 per cent. So the law as it now stands is that people who are providing 90 per cent of care are getting 100 per cent of payment, as you know. What that means is we do not go behind that. Centrelink has no reason to know what the numbers are—where there is a 10-90 split. I cannot give you those answers because, unless the other parent has claimed, it is not possible to quantify.

—But isn't there also a group of parents who might well be getting 100 per cent of the benefit but providing only 70 per cent or 80 per cent of the care currently? They are going to be major losers as a result of this provision because they will be losing 10 per cent of their benefit automatically. You cannot quantify that. You are very keen to talk about the losers and our amendments, but you cannot tell us the losers in your proposition.

speech.para: We accept this is a balancing act; it was a point I made in the second reading debate. That is why we are not convinced by your arguments. You have not told us the other side of the coin, and that is why we have moved this amendment. We are concerned about the impact. I also want to know whether or not that 10 per cent that will be saved will automatically be paid to the non-custodial parent.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I answered that: I said yes.
—So the non-custodial parent will automatically receive 10 per cent of the benefit?

—If they are providing 10 per cent of the care. Currently there is an unfair situation where somebody who is not giving 100 per cent of the care is getting 100 per cent of the payment. Most people would not regard that as fair. Surely the system that you endorsed in June last year is a fairer system—people get paid for the proportion of care that they are providing.

—I presume that means that you will also be amending the Child Support Act in coming months to reflect that because, as I understand it, the 70-30 provision is reflected in the Child Support Act. It seems to me that there is a live issue about whether someone who provides less than one day a week in care is meeting a direct proportion of the costs as compared to the parent who is providing the home, the clothing, buying the shoes, providing the education—meeting all those expenses. I do not think anyone argues—I do not think you would, Minister—that the percentage of care automatically corresponds with the percentage of the costs. One of the concerns that we have is that 10 per cent represents less than one day a week. So I suspect that, in the majority of cases where this is applied, it represents one weekend a fortnight in terms of the care arrangements I am familiar with regarding children in these sorts of arrangements. Therefore, you have to make a judgment about whether or not they are meeting the full share that the percentage of care represents in terms of the costs, given that the custodial parent is providing the majority of care, purchasing the clothes, providing the education—doing those sorts of things. That is why we have some concerns about the arrangements.

speech.para: But I want to take you back to this question as to who the losers are out of your proposition. It seems to me that there may be a variety of arrangements in care and that these people are automatically going to lose 10 per cent of their current payment even though the other partner may not want it. You were quite disparaging about our attempt to talk about parents coming together and reaching agreement. I accept that those things are difficult, but your provision is to automatically take 10 per cent of the payment off those custodial parents. I am not sure that that is a fairer or more rational way. You have not even consulted those parents about whether they want that to occur. What you are saying to me is that you will do that automatically, and I am not sure that that is a preferable outcome.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I think that is a misreading of what the government is doing. The government is actually recognising what is actually happening and what is agreed between the parents. If it is actually happening, why shouldn't the payments reflect the amount of care that is being given? I heard what Senator Evans had to say about the costs of, if you like, the principal carer, but there are quite substantial costs for anybody who is caring for a child every second weekend, half the holidays or every weekend. I understand that, in percentage terms, that is in the mid to upper 20s—approaching 30 per cent. That is a major commitment of your time to your children but it is also a major cost in providing two homes for your children. But do not forget that, in addition to this, the person who is giving, if you like, the secondary care is also providing financial support for the primary carer to enable that education that they are providing or whatever else that you mentioned.
—And that is calculated elsewhere, is it?

—Yes, it is calculated elsewhere but you have to factor this in. We are talking about a dynamic family—dynamic in one sense and with difficulties and problems in another sense because they have broken up—and they have to try to make sure that the new type of family life is the best possible for the children. If you have parents who are prepared to provide not only what they are required to give by law—that is, their child support payments—but also a meaningful secondary home for their children, they are spending a lot of money and time on their children. Do you suggest that that should not be reflected in the payment that would go to that parent for the proportion of time they are actually giving? I am really only concerned that you are allowing a veto between parents who may have difficulties about access and difficulties from time to time about whether child support payments are late or not—you know the typical patterns; that you are putting a veto on the secondary carer getting their entitlement for the percentage of time they are actually giving to care. I cannot imagine that you would think that was fair—unless that is patronising.

—I have a number of questions for the Minister for Family and Community Services to answer—basically providing her with the opportunity to convince me of her argument. I guess I am starting from a point of needing to be convinced. Firstly, I want to get to this issue that we are overturning something that the parliament agreed to when we passed the Family Assistance Act in, I think, June last year. I accept that it is possible for people to have inadvertently accepted something that they did not realise was in there, particularly given everything that was happening at that particular time, and that the introduction of that fairly major piece of legislation was put through fairly quickly. There were all sorts of reasons for that, and I am not necessarily criticising that process. But, even looking at it now, I am not able to see how this very significant change to implement a new shared care arrangement with this 10 per cent threshold was contained within that legislation.

speech.para: Section 25 of the act mentions a 10 per cent threshold. But, as I read it, that is basically there as a cut-off point to prevent people being able to claim to be the sole claimant of the family tax benefit rather than necessarily to implement a whole new pattern of shared care and shared payment. It is certainly not something that was referred to in the second reading speech and it seems to me quite a significant change. I would ask the minister to outline exactly where in the existing legislation this whole shared care arrangement with the 10 per cent threshold is. What component of the legislation that we agreed to last year is she suggesting that we are completely overturning? Is it simply section 25 or is there some other part of it that I have not picked up on properly?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —In answering Senator Bartlett's questions about the consideration by parliament last year, this is a useful opportunity to put on the record just what did happen. The inclusion of a 10 per cent threshold was clearly stated in the legislation that was passed in June last year. The particular section involved was section 25 of the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) Act 1999. It was also clearly described in the explanatory memorandum for the bill, with an example of how it would operate. The legislation was considered by the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee, as you might recall. The committee received submissions from four organisations, a public hearing was held on 13 May 1999 and it reported later that month. One of the submissions, which came from ACOSS, noted in relation to the treatment of shared care that the introduction of a new structure of family assistance `provides an opportunity to make progress towards a more suitable system than we currently have'. The Senate thus had the opportunity to examine and to raise with the government any concerns that it had on the eligibility rules for family tax benefit, and no such concerns were raised at that time in relation to shared care.

speech.para: Going on to the further questions that Senator Bartlett asked, I said earlier that the opposition's amendment is superficially attractive because it does have the appearance of trying to strike a reasonable balance as to the situations in which payment can be shared below a 30 per cent threshold—and Senator Bartlett was asking about thresholds—but it fails to acknowledge that there is not currently a 30 per cent threshold for family allowance, which is the main payment that is being rolled into the family tax benefit. The opposition have been trying to paint a picture that family allowance is based on a 30 per cent threshold, and I think that is perhaps because they make a connection with the child support legislation, which stands separately. Therefore, they would paint a picture that the government is thereby reducing the threshold to 10 per cent. The true picture is that there is no threshold percentage for family allowance now.

The amendment from the opposition fails to make it clear that the proposed discretion to allow sharing between 10 per cent and 30 per cent will not apply at all for many parents. The reason for that is the secretary's discretion can only apply if both parents agree for the secretary to determine a percentage between 10 and 30 per cent, and if one parent does not agree then the discretion does not apply. I do not think that is what you really want, Senator Evans. I cannot imagine you do. I would urge you to think again.

talk.start.para: —I wish to go back to the original issue of section 25 in the existing act, which the minister quoted. Section 30 of that legislation specifically stated that only one individual was eligible for the family tax benefit at the same time. It would seem to me that was the wording of what was in the then bill at the time. I know this amending bill seeks to remove section 30 but the bill that we agreed to last year specifically stated that only one individual would be eligible for the family tax benefit at any one time, as I read it. So, in terms of the argument of what the Senate actually unanimously agreed to last year, I think that puts it in a bit of a different situation in terms of this fundamental issue of whether or not we are moving to a system of splitting the family tax benefit between two different people.

speech.para: I acknowledge what the minister is saying about the existing arrangements under family allowance but, of course, there are different arrangements in relation to child support legislation and a number of other existing payments. The current family tax payment uses 30 per cent, child support uses a 30 per cent minimum and I think a number of other payments provide no opportunity for splitting at all. So it still seems to me that it is not so much an issue of whether or not we should have a shared care component in the legislation perhaps but where that percentage line is, which is what the amendment that we are discussing goes to. It still seems to me to be a significant shift to go to 10 per cent. Perhaps the minister could outline a bit more why 10 per cent is such a good idea and why 30 per cent is not. That might provide some assistance.

Section 30 of last year's bill does not prevent the sharing of the family tax benefit. It may be useful if I read out the reference in the explanatory memorandum of last year's bill. An example of the operation of section 25 is the situation where parents are separated and one parent, parent A, has the care of the child at all times except for one weekend every month, which is when the other parent, parent B—pursuant to a contact order—has the care of the child. In this scenario, there is a pattern of care each month, during which the child is an FTB child of two individuals at different times during the period. In this scenario, parent B has the care of the child for two days each month—that is, less than the 10 per cent requirement in section 25. Parent B would therefore not be eligible for FTB for the child for the two days each month during which time the child was in his or her care. In this scenario, the secretary would have the discretion to determine that parent A was eligible for FTB for the child for the two contact days of parent B. But, of course, under the amendments coming forward from the opposition, that secretarial discretion would not work unless the parents were agreed.

In response directly to Senator Bartlett about the 10 per cent issue, I would argue that 10 per cent is a reasonable test of material care. You must recognise that, even at that level of care, caring for the child incurs significant costs which cannot be ignored. Remember that this parent is also being required to pay child support, so it is in that context. Research that has been done quite recently in Australia shows that parents with that level of care or more incur relatively significant costs, because they need to provide a bedroom, they need appropriate furnishing for children of different ages, they need to provide food and clothes, and children get sick with parent B as they do with parent A. Of course, they also want to have some entertainment together. You must acknowledge that 10 per cent is a reasonable test of material care—after all, we want to encourage the maximum amount of contact. Ideally, we would like them to have fifty-fifty contact, or we would like them to live together and not have any of these arrangements. But surely we do not discourage somebody who, perhaps because of their own ill-health or disability or because of huge work commitments, has limited contact. For some people at a particular stage of life, it is very difficult to put in much more than 10 per cent. But, if you do not give them any recognition that that 10 per cent is significant in the child's life, you are sending a message of `Why bother?' to that parent. I fear that we would not be able to build on that as the relationship developed. It seems to me that even 10 per cent is to be encouraged and supported so that that percentage may grow, as and when the opportunity presents itself for that parent to give more time.

talk.start.para: —I would like to make a couple of comments. I do not agree with Senator Newman's last comments. I accept that we should be encouraging both parents, custodial and non-custodial, to take a role in the care. I do not think any of the measures particularly send a message to one parent of `Why bother?' There is no doubt that, whatever arbitrary level you set, there will be arguments about whether they have nine per cent care or 11 per cent care. And, quite frankly, once couples—
—That is why the discretion is there.

—There is no discretion in this. The arbitrary decision is that they will receive 90 per cent to 10 per cent—that is one of the points I am making. To get back to the central point, I understand that the government applied a 70 per cent-30 per cent split arrangement for many years. That applied in the child support legislation, it applied in the family tax initiative and it applied in the family allowance until the Federal Court decision. It seems to me that the onus is on the government to prove why we should move from the 70-30 split to the 90-10 proposition they are advocating currently. The government have to prove why we ought to move to that. The minister has made some arguments as to what they are doing administratively, but I think the key issue is that the minister has to establish the efficacy of splitting allowances at that low level of care. Traditionally, we have not split allowances at that low level of care. The 70-30 split has been accepted in other legislation. As I said, it applied in the family allowance until it was knocked off in the courts. It applied in the family tax initiative, as I understand it. We are moving to a lower level of care at which we decide to split the payment. That is a decision for this parliament to make, but the onus is on the minister to prove the case for that. We heard some reference to research. The staff of the shadow minister responsible, Mr Swan, asked for that research when they were briefed about the justification for the 10 per cent level. In explaining it then, the minister asked the rhetorical question, `Surely you would agree that 10 per cent is reasonable?' It seems to me that you have to make the case. Surely I would agree that 30 per cent is reasonable, or 20 per cent or 15 per cent. The point is that you are making a change; you have to convince the parliament on what basis that change should be made.
—I'm not—you are.

—I argue that you are making a change. There is no doubt that the provision in the original legislation slipped through. This is the first time we have had a debate about shared care. Senator Bartlett's—
—It was in the explanatory memorandum. It was in the committee.
—Minister, you would be the first to agree that we have had hundreds of pages of legislation in this package.
—But you also have members on the committee, and you are on the committee.

—Yes, and no-one has served more time on those committees than me. I have not seen you there, but I have been there for hours. The point is that this is complex legislation. There are hundreds and hundreds of pages of legislation, and I do not think any minister of the Crown pretends to be on top of every part of the detail, let alone expects every senator or every member of the committee to be. This is the first time that we have had a debate about what we see as a substantial change in approach—that is, about the question of shared care. Senator Bartlett is quite right to say that that went through to the keeper. We did not have a debate about it. It seems that we are able to make changes to parenting payment conditions on the run. The integrity of the package, the integrity of the information mailed out to Australian families, seems to be able to be altered if the government is under enough political pressure to allow for the parenting payment changes. So it seems to me that the argument that the minister adopts about the previous debate on the legislation and about the information is not really convincing. I have got the booklet in front of me now, and I do not think that the sort of proposition we are advocating today would cause too much difficulty.

speech.para: The minister has not been able to give us the details of who are the losers from the government's change. I think that is an important consideration, and saying that you do not know or that you cannot find out just seems a bit too cute. The minister always seems to have a big figure and a big dollar cost for anything the Democrats or the opposition put up, but cannot tell us about the downside of the government's arrangements. The onus is back on the government to prove why we ought to be making these splits in payments at what are relatively low levels of care; levels which traditionally we have not applied, which we do not apply in the child support legislation and which we have not applied previously in the family area. To make the case, the minister made a passing reference to research. I would like to see it—there was no specific reference. What is it that justifies moving to that low level?

As I have said all along, it is a balancing act. I have not made any great claims for the Labor amendments. It is a judgment call about such things. This is a very complex area. We think one of the advantages of our approach is that it does encourage parents to work these things through together. We say that the government's approach is arbitrary in that arbitrarily thousands of people who currently receive the payment will have their payment reduced from 100 per cent to 90 per cent, even if the other partner has not applied or does not want it. That seems to me terribly arbitrary. So the claims that we are removing discretion do not sit well with what you are doing. You are immediately removing discretion. You are arbitrarily saying that they will lose 10 per cent of their payment if they have shared care, whereas they might be receiving 100 per cent now.

As I say, it is a judgment call. I do not think we have had the debate. I think it is an important issue which we should have debated the first time. I accept some responsibility that we did not have that debate then, that we did not pick it up in the first round of this package of legislation. It is the parliament's role to make those decisions. We do need to make this one. I think the onus is on the government to establish why we should move to the 90-10 split, given what they have done in other legislation and in previous legislation in this area in the life of this government. I do not think that case has been made out. We think the 70-30 split, which has a bit of a precedent to it, is a better arrangement and that is what we argue for.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The senator asked about the basis on which we talk about the costs of sharing care. I draw to his attention policy research paper No. 75, published by the Department of Family and Community Services in May 1999, entitled The behaviour and expenditures of non-resident parents during contact visits. It was produced under contract to the department by Murray Woods and Associates. I think that, in the interval when this legislation goes across to the House of Representatives, if this amendment were to be passed—I hope it will not be—perhaps it would be beneficial for the opposition to have a look at that paper as to why we would say that people providing 10 per cent of care should get that recognition in the system. That is the law now. That is what parents are being told is the law now and one million of them have already received that information in their letterboxes.

speech.para: Senator Evans referred to another issue, too, about discretion and about parents getting the fair percentage of care. There is a discretion in existing legislation that, if a parent has less than 10 per cent of care, the other parent can get 100 per cent. They have to meet at least the threshold of 10 per cent in order to get a share of the payment. The government would say that non-resident parents are trying to have contact with their children and, if we do not recognise that, we are sending a message which many men in Australia feel they are getting already. We heard only yesterday in the debate from Senator Harris, who was obviously speaking for a lot of people who feel disaffected by the family law system and the child support system, et cetera. If people are providing at least 10 per cent of care, this parliament has passed a clause which entitles non-custodial parents to get financial recognition for that. If this parliament were to overturn that, you will have even more people who are dissatisfied with the system. There are men who feel that the entire system is against them, and I do not think we want to encourage that attitude in Australia. We have all seen what it has led to in political activity from people who are obviously emotionally very disturbed by the break-up of their families.

This legislation has been passed by this Senate after a committee inquiry and the tabling of an explanatory memorandum which spelt out exactly what was happening. There was no attempt to hide it. If, on the eve of the new system, you take this away from people who are providing that care, I think that would be very unjust. This is not something which is a matter for party politics. I think it is very seriously a matter of supporting and cherishing families who have been through a lot of hard times by the time they get to this stage; it is a matter of saying that the parliament of Australia believes that even 10 per cent of care is better for kids than no care from the second parent.

talk.start.para: —I think it is probably best not to get into that whole debate about how fathers are perceiving they are being treated by child support as opposed to how mothers feel they are being treated, because it is a very difficult debate, as all people here would acknowledge. It is probably best not to frame these amendments in the context of that debate if we can help it. Nonetheless, I recognise very much the views and perceptions that the minister just mentioned in relation to people who do not have primary care of their child. I am sure she would acknowledge that there are also very strong feelings amongst people who do have primary care of their child about how the system is treating them, and we need to consider those as well in terms of what their perceptions are about any changes that may be made. I am sure the minister would be aware that there are some perceptions that this 10 per cent threshold is an extra blow for primary caregivers.

speech.para: I will not redebate the meaning of the existing section 30, but in terms of how it reads, where it specifically deals with the situation of two individuals who are not members of the same couple and are not living together, only one can be eligible for FTB in respect of that child at any given time. It still seems to me to read very much to prevent a splitting of the FTB payment. I do not necessarily want to disagree on that, backwards and forwards, ad infinitum.

There is one other question I would like to put to the minister. This original family assistance act was brought in as part of a very large number of bills that were part of the new tax system. I am sure each of us has different views about that overall new tax system but, again, there is not much point in revisiting that debate now. As part of people's assessments about the desirability and the overall fairness of that new tax system, there was a lot of modelling done by different people and differing economists. There was a lot of modelling published by the government demonstrating how people would all be better off. I just want to see an indication from them as to whether any of that modelling specifically included people getting only 90 per cent or 75 per cent of the new family tax benefit rather than 100 per cent, as might have been expected. I want to know whether that assessment of the `losers' Senator Evans was talking about will mean their payments will be reduced by a percentage—they will not lose it altogether, but it will be reduced by a percentage—and whether that reduction was factored in to any of the modelling that was done by Access Economics, NATSEM or whoever else at that time.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —First of all, Senator, you referred to section 30 in last year's legislation. That was the section in which there was fifty-fifty care between the parents, and that clause allowed one parent to be eligible in the first week and the other parent to be eligible in the second week. So I do not know that that is particularly relevant to what we have in front of us now. I am just wondering whether I could propose something to the chamber that might be a way out for everybody. I hear your concerns and I think my concerns are actually more serious than yours—like in a marriage, you know, we are inextricably bound.
—One marriage is enough for me, Senator Newman, with all due respect.

—One is enough for me, too. Perhaps I could make a suggestion. This legislation is already in place, and the information has gone out to parents, as I said. It would be very, very difficult for parents to have a sudden change in what has been sent to them. In addition, we are talking about $23 million a year of new administrative costs, and I do not think either the opposition or the Democrats would be supportive of that. But during the course of this coming year, if we monitor this measure, I could undertake that we will come back to the Senate and advise whether the concerns of the opposition have actually been borne out in fact. At this eleventh hour, it seems to me that it is not an unreasonable suggestion as a way forward for us all.

—I am usually the first to indicate that I am happy to try and work through problems. I think previously on social security bills and other related matters we have always attempted to find a solution. That is my basic approach here as well and, if the government is looking to find a way through it, we would be happy to be party to any talks that had a more constructive outcome than sometimes arrives by weight of numbers in the chamber on particular amendments. But I do not know that an offer to monitor is substantial enough to sway me at this stage. I accept the minister's bona fides in making that offer, and I appreciate that, but I think we would want something a bit more substantial. Having said that, I recognise that the Democrats vote with the government—it does not matter what I want and what I say—so I am always a realist about these things.

speech.para: If the minister has something constructive for resolving this that provides greater flexibility and alleviates our concerns, then we would be happy to talk about it. I do not know that in the chamber, on the run, is the way to do it. I am not sure that an offer given by the minister—given with, I am sure, all sincerity—is necessarily enough. I have serious concerns about the approach being taken. If the minister wants to adjourn the bill and have a discussion about a way through, the Labor Party are always amenable to that constructive approach to see if there is more common ground. But, as I said, I am not sure that the offer by the minister really takes us very far. It still leaves us with our particular problem. I am interested to hear what Senator Bartlett has to say. Maybe there is an alternative that the minister might want to consider that might find a middle road. Perhaps I will wait to hear what Senator Bartlett has to say.

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank the minister for that offer she has given. I think it is a good reflection of the fact that all of us, whatever angle we are coming from on this issue, recognise that it is a difficult and complicated one and one where we are trying to get the best outcome in balancing various issues. In terms of the way forward, I am of a mind at this stage to support the ALP amendment. It does not worry me whether the minister wants to have the vote taken and we pass the bill then talk it through while it goes back to the House of Representatives, or whether she wants to adjourn the bill now and we talk through firming up what she has suggested. Either way, we want to nail down a little more specifically how that process might best work before we back away from supporting the amendment. It does not really worry me whether the minister wants to do that through adjourning the bill while we figure that out or whether she wants to pass the bill and give the House of Representatives something useful to do for a change. We could look at it again if she threw it back to us and we could talk to her in the meantime.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The opposition can amend this legislation at any time in the future, so they are not being precluded from the opportunity to try again if they find that, over the course of the 12 months, their fears are borne out. I would have thought that all parties would understand full well now that the huge administrative load that we have all been carrying over the last few months is coming to a peak with 1 July approaching, and all the new requirements for the tax and social security systems are needed to keep things moving. I do not really agree that we could move down an adjournment track. With other legislation coming along behind, it will get swept aside and have difficulty getting back onto the list. My proposal was meant in good faith. There is still an opportunity for this amendment to be brought forward at a later date if the concerns are borne out in fact. The government therefore is not prepared to adjourn the debate and, of course, we cannot accept the amendments.
(Senator McKiernan)—For the record, I ask all concerned, if they have to bring their mobile phones with them into the chamber, to ensure that their mobile phones are turned off.
—I move amendment No. 4:

quote.para: (4) Schedule 2, page 243 (after line 12), after item 117, insert:
117A Section 132
Repeal the section.

speech.para: This provision deals with social security appeal rights. It is a matter we have debated on a couple of previous occasions in relation to the A New Tax System (Family Assistance) (Administration) Bill 1999 and the Social Security (Administration) Bill 1999 and appeals to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. The bill would require any new evidence that comes before the tribunal to be referred back to the original decision maker. We oppose that extra step as we think it would only make appeals more time consuming and complicated. We are not convinced that referring the matter back to the original decision maker is necessary for the evidence to be properly examined. If the tribunal is qualified to examine the appeal case, we believe it is capable of examining any new evidence in that case. We will again move our amendment, as we have in those previous bills, to preserve the current arrangements whereby the tribunal will consider any new evidence on its merits.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The amendment will not be opposed by the government.
