debateinfo.title: A NEW TAX SYSTEM (FRINGE BENEFITS) BILL 2000

cognateinfo.title: A NEW TAX SYSTEM (MEDICARE LEVY SURCHARGE—FRINGE BENEFITS) AMENDMENT BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 April, on motion by Senator Ellison:

motion.para: That these bills be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the A New Tax System (Fringe Benefits) Bill 2000 and the associated bill and will be addressing most of my remarks to the question of the taxation treatment of charitable institutions and not-for-profit organisations and the measures that are contained in the bills. Other senators from the opposition will address some of the broader economic issues and other issues in the bills. I do not profess to be expert in those areas, and I think Senator Sherry and others will address some of those areas. I have taken an interest in this particular measure and its impact on the charitable and not-for-profit sector, mainly because of my shadow ministry responsibilities and also because of the inquiry into the goods and services tax conducted by the community affairs committee last year when a range of these issues were raised constantly with us and when, to be brutally frank, a lot of organisations said that the impact of the FBT changes would be more serious for them than any of the GST changes because much of the not-for-profit area was largely GST free and the FBT changes were going to have a very serous effect on their ability to provide services.

speech.para: I move a second reading amendment on behalf of the opposition:

quote.para: Omit the words after “That”, substitute:

“further consideration of the bills be an order of the day for the day after the day on which a report is tabled in the Senate of an independent inquiry established by the Government, after consulting the not-for-profit sector on membership and terms of reference, to:
(a) investigate and update the definitions of `public benevolent institution' and `charitable institution' for the purposes of tax law; and
(b) inquire into the appropriate taxation treatment of charitable and not-for-profit organisations and the public hospital sector”.

speech.para: In moving this amendment, Labor are seeking to ensure that the debate about this bill is an informed debate. I will come back to this theme later in my speech, but we are seeking to make sure that the decisions we make on the taxation treatment of the charitable and not-for-profit sector are informed decisions. Our main thesis is that we are not in the position to do that at the moment and that we do not have enough information about the impact of these changes. I think the GST community affairs committee inquiry threw a lot of light on some of those problems, but we still have not come to terms with the serious impact these changes may have on the not-for-profit sector and particularly on the services they deliver to the most disadvantaged in the community—the disabled, the poor, the aged and the Aboriginal medical sector.

These are very serious issues. Our major concern is that we do not have enough good information about the impact on those organisations and that we should not be making massive changes to their taxation treatment without that information. It is the case that Labor had supported a position prior to the last election very similar to the government's which sought to cap fringe benefits tax arrangements. We still support the need for capping, the need for transparency and the need for accountability in terms of these provisions. I do not think that there is anybody in this chamber who has an alternative view. We are arguing about the level of the cap, how it is applied and who it is applied to. I want to make it very clear that the Labor Party do support the cap. We are most dissatisfied with the current arrangements whereby informal advice from the tax office is provided to organisations. They have been basically advised that 30 per cent salary packaging is acceptable and that, provided they do not go over that limit, the tax office will not call on them or ask them to assist them with their inquiries. So it has become a bit of a benchmark in the industry. That is not a very satisfactory way of doing it, and we support the view of the government that we need to regulate that and that we need to find a much better and more transparent way of dealing with this issue.

Before I continue, I just want to say that, in terms of the second reading amendment, we are obviously looking to defer consideration of these FBT changes for not-for-profit organisations and charitable institutions. That is the impact of our amendment. We are not proposing to delay the rest of the bill and clearly we are suggesting by this measure that, if we are successful with the amendment and the government wants to continue proceeding with the rest of the bill, we will be happy to facilitate that. I understand that there are other measures in the bill about grossing up the formula for fringe benefits that are not the subject of the concern I am expressing now, and we would anticipate those going ahead. But we are concerned to deal with the issues of the impact of the FBT on the not-for-profit sector that I have just raised.

It is important that we get some certainty into this issue, because there are people currently working in not-for-profit, public hospital and charitable institutions who are unclear as to what their current conditions of employment are. Because of the government's announcement of 1 April as the operative date, people actually do not know what their current conditions of employment are. Most employers have been slow to make changes because they know that the bill has not been passed. They know there is a live debate in the parliament about the conditions that ought to be applied to the not-for-profit sector. There are people who operate under awards, under agreements and in unregulated employment conditions who have a set of employment arrangements that have been thrown up in the air. They do not know how they stand. Like other senators, my office has been getting lots of calls from people saying, `What does this mean for us? How do I arrange our affairs? Have I effectively just had a salary reduction?' and we cannot answer those questions. It is important that we get some certainty to it, that we get something that allows people to operate with a degree of certainty and allows them to plan. I am sure the government says, `Well, if we can just pass the legislation, everything will be certain,' and in a sense that is right. But there are issues we think need to be debated and resolved, and we do not think the government's approach is necessarily the correct one.

The issue was the subject of submissions to the Community Affairs Committee inquiry into the government's tax package which reported to the Senate in March last year. However, at the time the government signalled that it was unable to comprehensively examine the impact of the proposed FBT changes. In October last year, Labor called for an independent inquiry into this issue. We gave the government notice that we were concerned about the evidence arising from those inquiries, that we were concerned about the evidence being put forward by the charitable and not-for-profit sector, and that we thought an independent inquiry into this issue was warranted. The government has ignored that request. While the government may want to claim that it is a bit late to be moving this amendment, the reality is that we have had a consistent position calling for some sort of inquiry to resolve some of these important public policy issues at stake here and get some clarity as to some of the issues that are causing confusion.

talk.start.para: —For many months.

—Yes. We have had this position since October and we thought that the government may well adopt it. We have advocated a Ralph style inquiry into the not-for-profit sector, to give them the same sort of treatment that the business community received, in terms of an overall look at the taxation treatment of the charitable sector.
—As have the Democrats.

—Yes, the Democrats have as well. I think there has been a consensus in the sector that that would be useful. As a result of this legislation being put off and the government not responding to that request, we are now in the situation where the operative date has passed, we have not got legislation in place and we have not had a resolution of those public policy issues.

speech.para: In my amendment today, I try and throw the issue back to the government in the sense of them consulting with the sector about having an independent inquiry. I also have a motion on the Notice Paper about a Senate committee inquiry. Being frank and to be fair to the senators on the committee, including me, it is a second-best option. I do not think we have the same level of expertise and resources that an independent inquiry could bring to the issue. We would do a professional and reasonable job, but I think that a Ralph style inquiry would be a better and more comprehensive option and one which would take those great public policy issues a bit further. If this approach is rejected by the government, then we will pursue the Senate inquiry approach. That issue has been on the Notice Paper for some time. At the request of the Democrats, I have delayed it as we have tried to find a way through these issues. As I say, I think the independent inquiry would be the better option given the scale of the changes proposed, the number of organisations affected and the impact on the public hospital sector, which is going to be enormous. I think we are talking about $700 million over the next four years, so these are major changes to the taxation treatment. They need a proper examination.

I accept that the government has now made some changes and the bill currently before the Senate includes a higher limit of $25,000 for the cap for charitable and not-for-profit organisations. The fact that the government has increased the FBT concession limit to charitable and nonprofit organisations is an admission, I think, that the original limit was too low and would have unfairly reduced their ability to deliver services to the disadvantaged. The government has begun to recognise that problem and what it means for services to the most disadvantaged in our community. I am not clear why the government chose the $25,000 limit and how that new higher limit will avoid cuts to services, but it is a sign that the government is trying to deal with the issue. The reality is that even with a higher limit the proposed change will still raise significant amounts of revenue, which means significant cuts to the operational budgets of charitable and nonprofit organisations. An enormous impact is still going to be felt by these organisations.

The proposed limit on FBT concessions is a significant change to the taxation treatment of charitable and nonprofit organisations and the public hospitals. Yet the only thing we know for certain about this change is that it will act to reduce the range of community and public hospital services they provide. At the time of the Senate inquiry last year, the government was unable to provide any detailed information on the modelling of the impact of the measure. This lack of information was noted in the inquiry's report to the Senate. More than a year after the proposed limits were announced, the government still refuses to or is unable to provide specific information on the impact of the proposed changes. We have no information on the extent of the use of the FBT concessions. We have no information on the pattern of the use of the FBT concessions and we have no information on the value of the FBT concessions to the charitable and nonprofit organisations and public hospitals. The figures on the revenues raised by the proposed FBT limits included in the bill are rough estimates at best. On the government's own figures, I have seen a number of different figures quoted. But they all indicate that over $700 million will be cut from the budgets of charitable and nonprofit organisations and public hospitals over the next four years.

While the government has been unable to provide detailed information on the impact of the changes it is proposing, the organisations that will be affected have done so. They presented submissions to last year's Senate inquiry and they have continued to lobby and provide evidence of the very real impact on the services they provide. Just a few of the organisations that presented evidence to the Senate inquiry included: the Spastic Centre of New South Wales, which would be forced to cut services to 370 school aged children, close a respite centre and cease services to 200 families in rural communities; Deafness Forum Australia, which would be forced to cut one in three staff; and the National Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisation, which has stated that all remote health services in the Northern Territory would be closed and many urban services would suffer cuts. These are very real impacts. They are impacts this parliament has to grapple with seriously. We need to come to terms with it. The Labor view is that we ought not make changes when we do not know the impact of those changes and we ought not make changes that we have been warned will seriously affect those in the community who can least protect themselves. I am sure that is a concern for all senators on all sides of the chamber.

The government has also refused to address the need for compensation to ensure that essential services to the disadvantaged are not reduced as a result of the proposed changes. Clearly, that is an alternative we could consider. It is worth remembering that the issue was examined by the 1995 Industry Commission report into charities. I note that Senator Woodley and I both spoke on it on that occasion. We are still involved in the issue. At the time the commission stated:

quote.para: Given the major benefits which [charitable and non-profit organisations] as a whole currently derive from input tax exemptions, however, the Commission considers that any proposal to remove these benefits should include alternative ways of providing the same aggregate level of government assistance to the sector.

speech.para: That principle was applied at a time when this was a very small issue compared with what it is today. The growth in fringe benefits tax exemption usage has been phenomenal since then, driven, in part, by a couple of state governments and by the demands placed on the charitable and not-for-profit sector for more services in difficult times. Until there is an independent inquiry into the use of the FBT concessions, we cannot know what the impact of the proposed limits are and we cannot know what reductions to services will occur as a result. We therefore cannot be sure that we can protect those services to the least disadvantaged in our community. In the short time left to me, I want to mention that there is a real need to look at the basis of many of these concessions. There is a lot of concern about the definition of `PBI' and the definition of `charities'. As I understand it, we have to refer back to an act of the British parliament from the 16th century. It is a funny way to build a new tax system for the 21st century, and it seems to me that we can do better.

I turn briefly to the role of the Democrats. I have had some very constructive discussions with them and I hope we can continue to work our way through these issues. What we are proposing is that the inquiry precede debate on this bill, that we have the information at our fingertips when we debate the bill. I urge the Democrats to adopt that approach. I am concerned that they may be looking at adopting an approach of voting for some sort of inquiry but will deal with the bill now. We do not have the information that allows us to have an intelligent public policy debate about the legislation. We are not informed by that inquiry. If we make the decision and have the inquiry afterwards, it raises the question: why have an inquiry? I know that the Democrats, like the Labor Party, are interested in a broader inquiry than—

talk.start.para: —Senator, it is always nice to know what the results of an inquiry are before you institute one. I am sure it is a policy you pursue, and Telstra does come to mind. But I digress. I make the point to the Democrats that, while I know there are wider issues, at the heart of this is the FBT and its impact on the charitable and not-for-profit sector. There is also the question of the GST. I understand the sensitivities about that. If we are serious about having a proper public policy debate about how all those taxes impact on the sector and its ability to deliver services, we have to do it in a holistic way. We need to have the inquiry and then make decisions about the taxation treatment of those institutions. If we do not have the inquiry first, we will be making these decisions tomorrow morning without the benefit of that information. I think it would be a very brave senator who made the claim that we really know what the impacts of these changes are. I do not think the government knows and I do not think the Senate knows either. I would make a plea to the Democrats to support our second reading amendment because it does allow us to have that proper and informed public policy debate, to have a Ralph type inquiry report to inform the Senate's work and to inform proper legislation in this country. We would get a much better result from such an approach.

speech.para: Clearly, the Labor Party operates in a political environment where it does not have the numbers. If the amendment is defeated and the bill goes to the committee stage, we will vote on any amendments proposed and we will have to take a stand on each of the issues. We would prefer to do that with the benefit of a proper inquiry, proper modelling and proper research. We think we would get a much better public policy outcome if we dealt with it in that way. A proper inquiry would inform the Senate debate, allow us to make informed decisions and allow us to have a bit of a community debate too about the proper taxation treatment of charities before we moved to deal with the FBT limits. There are, of course, questions about the operative date and so on, but our preferred position, since October, has been to have that proper inquiry, to recognise the evidence we received from the GST inquiry that there were serious problems with the implementation of these FBT proposals—to have an inquiry to get that information—to have an informed debate and then to deal with the bill. That is our preferred option. I hope we get some support for it. If not, obviously we will move on to dealing with the substance of the bill and making decisions accordingly.

talk.start.para: —First of all, I wish to address the concerns that Senator Evans has just expressed. Certainly, in intention, the Australian Democrats will support the opposition's second reading amendment. It may be that we will still want to change some of the words. We can do that by negotiation tomorrow because obviously the second reading debate of the A New Tax System (Fringe Benefits) Bill 2000 will not be finished tonight and will continue for some time tomorrow. By and large we intend to support the opposition's second reading amendment, but it may be that we can negotiate a change to some of the words. Senator Evans, we will find that out when we have that conversation with you. I just give you that assurance.

speech.para: I agree with just about everything you have said, in particular that we do not have the kind of information we really need in order to do justice to this debate, and certainly in order to do justice to the charity, churches and not-for-profit sector. The very fact that I have had to use an extended description points to the problem that we have in law. The basis upon which most of these matters are dealt with is a law that goes back some 400 years in English law. Someone told me today that, in fact, it goes back further than that—to the 1100s. I do not know how we can ever expect in a modern society to be basing legislation on that kind of proposition. So we need the kind of inquiry Senator Evans described. I hope that with goodwill on all sides, and maybe a further discussion about wording, we will achieve what Senator Evans has described.

In the few minutes that are left to me tonight, I want to talk about the motivation for the government introducing this legislation, because the motivation that has led to the debate and the legislation which we have before us is very clear. I would remind the Senate—and I do not know whether senators have forgotten this—that it was the Ralph report on business taxation which proposed that, in order to pay for a reduction in the company tax rate, the government should abolish the fringe benefit tax exemption to this sector. That was a proposal in the Ralph report. Quite clearly, the government were not game to do that. The roof would have fallen in, I am sure, and they realised that. But they did propose a kind of half-way measure, that is, there should be a $17,000 cap across the board on charities, on churches, on hospitals—you name it, wherever there was an exemption in the past, then a $17,000 cap should be imposed in the future. That of course was intended to raise over $200 million, which in effect would achieve what the Ralph report proposed, that is, to compensate for the loss of revenue in lowering the company tax rate.

The churches and the charities reacted very strongly to that, and for good reason. They know that the Industry Commission—or Productivity Commission as we now call it—some years ago did a major inquiry into charities. In fact, the report they produced was quite thick. It showed that some of the charities and some of the services which they provided were overusing the fringe benefits tax exemption, to such an extent in a few cases that I think one could use the word `rorting' without being unfair. That was true. When that Productivity Commission report came down, the major churches and the major charities realised that there had been some overuse of the fringe benefits tax exemption. So they went and had extensive conversations with the Australian Taxation Office. It was never put in writing, and so the Treasurer keeps on reminding us that there is no legislation and no written advice to actually underline the position I am putting—but it was very clear. I have spoken to charities across the country and all of them have reported that this is what happened: they had a conversation with the tax office; it was not written down; it was not put into legislation. That is true, but all of the charities and churches, et cetera, adopted voluntarily a 30 per cent cap on salary packaging using the fringe benefits tax exemption. That was the agreement reached. The government has totally ignored that. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979: Report of Attorney-General's Department

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: This is a document that the Attorney-General must have prepared each year to fulfil his obligations under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. The report from the Attorney-General and the act that he is in compliance with are often thought of as giving permission to policing authorities to intercept telephones, telegrams and no doubt other communications. I see Senator Alston in the chamber. The onset of technology in this area is incredible. The policing authorities find it very useful to listen in to these conversations and, indeed, to tape them in the course of gaining intelligence and evidence for prosecutions. The act allows all that.

Fundamentally, the act is about protecting our privacy. I think it is very useful to talk to a report like this to bring to our mind that the concept of privacy still has currency, that there is some protection for privacy in the legislation that comes before this chamber and that ultimately becomes law in this country. The issue of privacy is a big one. It is a big issue in Europe and elsewhere. We have laws regulating privacy for the public sector but there are no laws that protect privacy in the private sector. I know that the Attorney-General, Mr Williams, was intent on getting such legislation through when he first took over the office, and no doubt he is still intent on that happening. It would be good to see legislation brought in to protect privacy. We all want our privacy but, unfortunately, moves are not made that would enable us to have it to the extent that we would want. Indeed, the protection is so feeble that maybe it is not the protection of privacy we want but legislation that says there ought to be an equality of possession of information so that, if we are not going to have privacy, at least we will have as much information about things as everybody else does, because knowledge and what you know about others, of course, is a great strength in any relationship one might have.

Since this act was brought in, the number of authorities that have been able to tap into electronic communications between people has grown. On 28 October 1988 the Victorian police were given possession of it. I must say that is a very significant date because it is the birthday of my wife, Lillian, but that is just an aside that I put in as I go through, Mr Acting Deputy President. The New South Wales Crime Commission was given the power on 30 January 1989, and so on. And I notice that the New South Wales Police Integrity Commission got permission to use these powers on 14 July 1998. There is always a legitimate reason for giving powers to authorities, but there is always a danger that the very purpose of the act—that is, to protect our privacy—becomes damaged because of this. If you look at the number of taps that are allowed, they do not seem greatly excessive. But I think it is always wise for somebody to step up on an occasion like this simply to say, `Yes, the Attorney-General has to have this report prepared and it is proper for us to look at it.' It is proper for us to remember that, really, it is about protecting privacy and that, as the growth of these powers increases, it is always timely for somebody to at least mention that the matters put out by the Attorney-General are being taken note of. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner: Social Justice Report 1999

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: In moving that the Senate take note of this document, I think it is very important that, with both documents Nos 2 and 3, given the current debate we are having surrounding mandatory sentencing and the current situation we find ourselves in with regard to the stolen generation, this report in particular is tabled before the federal parliament this week. These documents come about as a result of a requirement under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 that the Social Justice Commissioner be required to report annually on the `enjoyment and exercise of human rights by Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders'. One might find it rather ironic that, in this current debate, the commissioner is required to report on the enjoyment and exercise of human rights because, if you read his report on social justice, you will find that the situation is in fact far from that.

It is interesting to note that, in his report, the commissioner concentrates quite heavily on the situation occurring in the Northern Territory. In fact, about 80 per cent of this report refers to the situation in which Aboriginal people find themselves in the Northern Territory. It seems that that Territory is slowly becoming a blot on our national reputation with regard to indigenous people. This social justice report is the first by Dr William Jonas. It was presented to the Attorney-General on 20 January. It looks at four key issues: young people and human rights, identity, mandatory sentencing and bilingual education. It outlines some very useful statistics in relation to indigenous people and population, unemployment, secondary education, mortality and, of course, contact with the criminal justice system. It goes into some detail about mandatory sentencing and bilingual education. I also want to note that it makes some very interesting statements about statehood, the way in which statehood was treated in the Northern Territory, the way in which indigenous people voted and perhaps why they voted to reject statehood. It is interesting to see that, throughout his report, Dr Jonas makes a number of very interesting comments about the reconciliation process. In particular, in his summary of the statehood process in the Northern Territory on page 24 he says:

quote.para: A reconciliation process which is based on anything less than negotiation over these principles—

speech.para: the principles he is referring to are the principles of the reconciliation of distinct rights of indigenous people in the Northern Territory that flow from the now famous Kalkaringi statement—

quote.para: will join proposals such as the Social Justice Package as an empty, unfulfilled commitment to social justice for all Australians.

speech.para: It is interesting to note that the report actually makes a number of statements along these lines. He looks at the extent of indigenous disadvantage, from the perspective our future and our young people. He profiles what is happening with indigenous people between the ages of 15 and 29 years. He also considers the issues that the participants in the indigenous young people's forum considered: where they are, where they are going, and what they believe they need to do in order to contribute to their identity as indigenous people. He makes some very brave comments about the attempt by the Northern Territory government to abolish the bilingual education programs, and he writes about rights to education, language, cultural difference and self-determination for indigenous people. Given that this is the first report from the Social Justice Commissioner along these lines, it has some very telling points to make, particularly, as I said, about the extent of indigenous people in the Northern Territory. It makes very interesting reading and I have no doubt that I will continue my remarks at length on this matter.

talk.start.para: —As Senator Crossin has said, this is the first report from Dr William Jonas, the third Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. It is good to see that Dr Jonas acknowledges the great contribution made by his predecessors. On page 26 he has put in a paragraph which I think is worth repeating. He says:

quote.para: Dr Mick Dodson, the first Social Justice Commissioner, set the highest standards of advocacy for the human rights of Australia's Indigenous peoples and his achievements are lasting. Zita Antonios, who filled the role in an acting capacity for eighteen months, maintained this role in a period of intense public debate, increased workloads and great change. Both are to be warmly congratulated for their efforts. I have inherited from them a strong legacy from which to continue to advocate for the rights of Indigenous Australians.

speech.para: Dr Jonas sums it up well and properly pays tribute to Dr Dodson and Zita Antonios.

As Senator Crossin has so eloquently put it, this report deals with the criminal justice system and its effect on the indigenous community, particularly young indigenous people. We have not got time to go through the report in detail, but it does show that the matters Senator Crossin raised are supported by considerable evidence. You only have to look at table 19, for example, `Imprisonment rate by age'. If you look at the imprisonment rate at ages 20 to 24, which is when young males in particular tend to get themselves into trouble, you can see the contrast between indigenous males and non-indigenous people.

There is a need to seek an answer to the problem that the criminal justice system presents to indigenous people. One way we might go about doing that is to at least have some empathy with indigenous people—indeed, with people who are in the criminal justice system generally. I do not mean that we should be in any way soft on crime, but sentences should be proportionate to the crime. It is not an easy matter to serve a sentence in jail. No-one who is listening to this speech would like to be put into jail, and it is not simply because of the experience of being in jail; it is also because of what it does to your social standing. Most people would be very concerned that their reputation would be greatly tarnished by going to jail. Just imagine turning up to apply for a job and, in the list of the experiences of your life, you had to say, `I've been to jail.' Just as we want a high reputation, so do those who go into the jail system. The term that is spent in jail is not the only concern in the issue of mandatory sentencing; it is the terrible damage done to a young person's reputation. The crime itself is bad enough, but the greatest condemnation that this society can put on any person is to send him or her to jail, thus fixing a stain upon his or her reputation—justly in many cases. We ought to be very careful about who we are going to put in jail and who we are going to mark with damage to their reputation. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner: Native Title Report 1999

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

speech.para: I want to take note of the native title report that has also been produced by the Social Justice Commissioner this week. The report is a requirement under section 209 of the Native Title Act. It reports annually on the operation of the Native Title Act and its effect on the exercise and enjoyment of human rights by Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders. I have to say from the outset that this is also not a particularly complimentary report on the activities of the government. It reveals the inadequacies of the Australian government's policies and practices in effectively dealing with the ongoing discrimination against indigenous peoples. It recommends a revised approach to indigenous equality. In this report Dr Jonas says:

quote.para: We need special remedial measures to overcome historically entrenched patterns of racial inequality, as well as active intervention to protect the distinct cultural characteristics of indigenous communities.

speech.para: He goes on to make a comment that public debate on indigenous issues has often been divisive, as we have seen recently, with scapegoating of indigenous people as somehow being privileged and enjoying special treatment compared with the general population. He goes on to say that the reality could not be further from the truth. In particular, this report considers the implications of the March 1999 decision of the committee on the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination, commonly known as the CERD committee. That committee has found that the federal government's 1998 amendments to the Native Title Act of 1993 are in breach of Australia's obligations under the convention. An inquiry is being conducted by the federal parliamentary joint native title committee.

The CERD committee considered the amendments according to the two fundamental requirements of the convention: to treat all people equally and in a non-discriminatory manner, and to ensure the effective participation of indigenous people in decisions which affect them. The committee found that the amendments to the Native Title Act are discriminatory and were implemented without the informed consent of indigenous people. This report is important because it looks at these two fundamental principles in relation to three areas: the inadequacy of the minimum standards which are required of state governments in their management of native title regimes, the impact of the registration test on native title claims, and the impact of the amendments in the Native Title Act in relation to the native title representative bodies.
The introduction to this report is very telling. It says:

quote.para: The native title story has told us that reconciliation is not about Indigenous people proving they can be reconciled to a non-Indigenous way of life. Rather it is about recognising Indigenous culture and giving it the same value and respect as that which is given to non-indigenous culture.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

talker.name: Abetz, Sen Eric
Senator ABETZ
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —On the same matter, it is important that some factual elements be reintroduced into the debate on the report of the committee on the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and to remind the Australian people about the way this committee operates. It has luminaries such as representatives from Cuba and China, who undoubtedly deal—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The point of order I raise is whether or not Senator Abetz has read the report and is actually speaking to the report, in which the composition of the CERD committee is not made mention of at all by Dr Jonas.
(Senator Sherry)—Senator Abetz's contribution is relevant to this particular report.

—If my comments in relation to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination were somehow irrelevant, I simply invite Senator Crossin to read the Hansard and her comments where she refers to the convention on the elimination of racial discrimination as well. I would have thought that if it was relevant to her it would be relevant for me as well.

speech.para: The Australian Labor Party are in this terrible dilemma at the moment. They will quote reports such as Dr Jonas's and other reports, but they will not tell us what they are going to do. That was so embarrassingly portrayed to the Australian people by the shadow minister Daryl Melham's quite pathetic performance on the Sunday program. When asked whether they would repeal those allegedly discriminatory sections of the Native Title Act, he was unable to commit himself to doing so. Similarly with Senator Crossin. All she does is to try to promote the report but does not say what they would do in government. Indeed, we have been invited by Senator Crossin in her comments to consider the findings of the committee on the elimination of racial discrimination. It would be interesting for the Australian people to be told that in the committee's recent report—this so-called independent committee—it only found its way clear in the reporting process to give two positives and 13 concerns to Australia. Indeed, if I can quickly explain, the UN committee classifies its reports into positive aspects and subjects of concern.

So, when they looked at Australia as a nation in relation to racial matters, what did they find? They found two positives and 13 concerns. But guess what? When they had a look at China they found six positives and only 10 concerns—three times as many positives as they were able to find for Australia and three fewer concerns than they found in Australia. Russia scored six positives as well and only four concerns. Guess what Cuba scored? One concern and four positives. So, if you were to decide which country to live in with respect to racially discriminatory practices and you read through the United Nations checklist of positives and concerns, you would undoubtedly choose Cuba according to the rationale of the committee of the United Nations that deals with the elimination of racial discrimination. Just take the tip: why is it that all the boat people seem to be wanting to come to Australia and not Cuba or China? I simply say to the people who sit on these United Nations committees: get a bit of rigour, get a bit of integrity, get a bit of factual information and get into the real world and then your reports may be considered with a degree of respect by the Australian people and, indeed, other people around the world.

In relation to the native title legislation, I completely reject that, in any way, it is racially discriminatory. I would simply say that it has been an outcome for the betterment of both the indigenous community and the Australian community at large.

talk.start.para: —That is not what Dr Jonas said.

—A lot of the debate has now gone out of native title to the extent that Senator Crossin's shadow minister is unable to identify any section that the Labor Party would repeal. They have not identified any section that they would repeal. It is a bit like the GST: `We are against it but we are going to keep it when we get into government.' Until the Labor Party come up with some realistic policies, they forfeit the right to be in government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

subdebateinfo.title: Greater Western Sydney: Impact of Olympic Games

talk.start.para: —I am not one to ride on the Olympic bandwagon, but September's Olympic Games will see one of the biggest celebrations in this nation for a very long time. The attention of the world will be on Sydney and, more precisely, on Greater Western Sydney. The immediate benefits of a successful bid for the Games are obvious for the region, but what are the medium and long-term impacts for the area? The world will focus its attention on Sydney when the Olympics arrive in September and it is vital for Western Sydney to take advantage of that unprecedented attention to ensure that the region continues long into the future to feel the benefits of hosting the Games.

speech.para: Most important of those impacts is the stimulus for economic growth. As one of the main industrial, agricultural and business centres in Australia, the Greater West's economic worth is $35 billion, with over 72,000 businesses and 1.5 million people. Western Sydney has to highlight the attractive investment and business opportunities the region has to offer. One of the region's most important attributes is its well-educated, productive and highly skilled work force. International companies are bringing their business to Sydney to exploit this valuable labour force to gain a foothold in the Asia-Pacific region. Crucial to this is the fact that 25 per cent of Sydney's work force are from non-English speaking backgrounds. They have valuable language skills and are ideally suited for operating in both Western and Asian business environments. The impact of business confidence and investment in Sydney's Greater West will be shown by the development of new industries. The IT industry is one which will have a major economic impact. According to recent reports, there are 18,000 people currently employed in IT in Western Sydney. The Greater Western Sydney Economic Development Board estimates growth in information technology of an expected 300 per cent over the next five years in some parts of the region—Wollondilly, in particular, I understand.

There have to be strategies in place to make sure that Sydney takes advantage of the international exposure of the Olympics and realises the full economic impact of the Games—and I will touch on just a couple of those. Firstly, there is Investment 2000, an Australian business venture aimed at developing links to business and investment companies within Asia by giving Australia as broad a coverage as possible during the running of the Games. The focus will be on the labour market's strong potential, including our high education levels, skills availability, the Asian language resource and competitive salary levels. Secondly, the Australian Technology Showcase will promote the innovative qualities of New South Wales and Australian emerging technology industries to international executives in business and the media. Finally, the Olympics Business Roundtable has developed a strategy known as `Australia Open for Business' that seeks to ensure that the best features of the economy are on display when the Olympic spotlight focuses here in September.

In relation to jobs growth, industry investment and infrastructure development, the Greater West's economy is expected to grow by an average of $1 billion over the next three years and $1.5 billion over the next six after that. As a result of hosting the Games it is expected that an extra 200,000 jobs will be created by 2003. Many of those will be in the newly developed IT&T industries as well as hospitality and tourism. In fact, the immediate impact of the Olympics is seen most dramatically in the investment in infrastructure development in the Greater West—take the Olympic site itself, for example. It is an incredible feat in engineering and construction. Its on-time completion is a testament to the Australian construction industry—completed, I might note, with minimal industrial action. The Homebush Olympic site is supplemented by the Dunc Gray Velodrome in Bankstown and the Penrith Lakes Olympic rowing course. All three venues create permanent landmarks for future generations to enjoy.

Three million dollars a day was spent on construction of the facilities for the Games, including the construction of the athletes village and a new rail loop built to increase commuter access to the site. A new urban park, twice the size of Centennial Park, has been established. It is part of 440 hectares of recreational parkland that covers the site. There is a public domain area that has the capacity to hold up to half a million people. The athletes village is an important development in the Greater West and will become a new suburb at the completion of the Games and the Paralympic Games. Named Newington, it will be the world's largest solar powered suburb. At a cost of $470 million, it will be completed in 2005. There will be an estimated 5,000 residents in the new suburb when the temporary dwellings have been removed and 2,000 permanent dwellings have been constructed. A primary school and other community facilities will be established out of the Games facilities. A business park development and neighbourhood retail centre will boost services in the surrounding region.

Even the proposed Parramatta rail link is another infrastructure development in the west stimulated by the Olympic economic boom. Costing $1.4 billion, it is expected to be completed by 2006 with an estimated patronage of 18.6 million people. We will obviously also have an increase in the numbers of tourists to the region, with an important flow-on effect for the entire economy of the Greater West. The Tourism Forecasting Council predicts an influx of 8.2 million visitors to our shores over the 21 days of the Games and the Paralympics after that. In the longer term the Games are predicted to attract 1.6 million tourists in the four years after the Olympics, according to the Tourism Forecasting Council. Of these, New South Wales can expect 1.1 million, providing a $4.2 billion windfall for the state's economy, as noted in a report from KPMG Management Consulting and Griffith University on this subject.

A most prevalent and culturally important impact of the Games is the very widespread development of sporting facilities in Western Sydney, giving the Greater West a very strong right to claim to be the sporting capital of the state, if not Australia. The Stadium Australia development was completed at a cost of $690 million and provides the largest outdoor venue in modern Olympic history. At the completion of the Games it will be reconfigured to seat 80,000 people. Even IOC President Juan Antonio Samaranch described the Sydney Aquatic Centre as `the best swimming pool I have seen in my life'. That 4,400-seat venue will play host to a wide range of events in the longer term, ranging from World Cup swimming to the local school swimming carnivals. The Olympic velodrome in Bankstown will provide a long-term legacy for the people of Western Sydney. Not only will it attract world and national cycling circuits but the infield can be easily reconfigured to host exhibitions and other cultural events.

The Olympic site construction is based on the principle of the Green Games. Environmentally friendly practices were adopted in the construction of all of the venues and that has had an important impact on Western Sydney with the restoration of wasteland and the establishment of parklands in particular. The major long-term effect of the Green Games on Western Sydney has been the restoration of the Homebush Bay site. It was a disused environmental wasteland, previously the site of an armaments store, a chemical company, a garbage dump and a slaughterhouse. Not surprisingly, over time it became severely degraded land. Waste Services New South Wales was given the responsibility for the removal of contaminants on the site, placing the toxic waste in consolidated pits at Homebush Bay. It also dealt with restoration of the mangrove at Homebush Bay so that waste which does run off the site is filtered out before it hits the water system. That clean-up, that mangrove management, is a major environmental achievement.

What was a major toxic wasteland and absolute eyesore has been transformed into a sporting and recreational landmark for the nation. In fact, by September 2000 there will be five million shrubs and native grasses planted around the site, including the planting of an additional 200,000 trees—an additional important environmental legacy for Western Sydney. These parklands are a much-needed recreational resource in Sydney's Greater West and the use of green construction techniques and products in the Olympic venues will provide invaluable experience for future developments in the construction industry.

Finally, there are obviously also cultural questions attached to the staging of the Olympics and the Paralympics and, most particularly, the question of art. Twelve innovative public art projects have been commissioned for display at the Olympics. At a cost of $7.5 million, they will be on display at Homebush and in other areas of Western Sydney. Homebush Bay itself will feature nine public art projects. Some of these will be free standing and others will be worked into the surrounding environment. They will provide a creative and interesting landmark that will be appreciated by both the people of the Greater West and the visitors to the area.

The Olympics obviously provide an extraordinary opportunity for the people of the Greater West of Sydney to showcase all the exciting prospects that we have to offer. The long-term impacts of hosting the Games are both exciting and enormously beneficial. There are trade and business opportunities for Western Sydney. They will provide jobs growth and investment into the long term. The more medium term tourism impacts of the Olympics and the Paralympics will also assist in economic growth. The environmental impacts of the Games, such as the new parklands, are significant and advantageous for the people of Sydney and beyond. Finally, we have the record of the great sporting and cultural legacies which will be enjoyed by all Australians but most particularly by the Greater West long into the future.

subdebateinfo.title: Auditor-General's Report: Retention of Military Personnel

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak tonight to Auditor General's report No. 35 of 1999-2000—Retention of military personnel. This was a matter that was introduced in the chamber earlier last week but at that time I could not draw attention to it in the detail that I wish to tonight. Therefore I wish to speak to it this evening as I have had a long interest in the Defence Force, particularly the Reserves.

speech.para: This is an important document and one of which we should take note. This report goes to the very heart of the Defence Force's ability to retain the highly trained, efficient, motivated men and women that form the core of our nation's Army, Navy and Air Force. It is of great economic, strategic and moral importance that our Defence Force maintains the best possible retention rate of its personnel, both officers and enlisted full time and reserve personnel. The retention rate is economically important. The cost to the taxpayer of the extensive training of our Defence Force personnel is indeed significant. The retention rate is also strategically important. The loss of officers and enlisted personnel from the Defence Force results in the degradation of the military's corporate knowledge and its ability to serve our nation's interests in time of crisis and need. The retention of our service personnel is also morally important. High rates of separation from the military indicate to me that we are not providing our Defence Force personnel with an appropriate employment environment. To do this to men and women who have chosen to defend our nation with their lives in times of crisis is morally reprehensible.

The Australian Defence Force's involvement in the INTERFET peacemaking contingent is a continuation of the long and justifiably proud history of service to this nation by its officers and enlisted personnel. However, it could be argued that this high level of service is under threat. According to the Auditor-General's report, the Australian Defence Force, in the last 12 months, experienced an overall separation rate of 14 per cent. If this figure was not cause for concern, then the staggering 26.73 per cent separation rate of women from the Army during 1996-97 is. This rate is nearly three times the overall rate of separation in the Australian Defence Force. Clearly, a separation rate of this magnitude must have a detrimental effect on the morale and efficiency of the Australian Defence Force. This cannot be allowed to continue. The Australian Defence Force spends in excess of $31 million a year on recruiting new personnel, yet the Auditor-General's report states:

quote.para: Defence's career management agencies appear to have minimal staff.

speech.para: Many members of the ADF who were interviewed as part of this report said:

quote.para: ... that they had rarely met a Defence career manager and did not feel they had any influence over their future.

speech.para: It was further reported that there `is no formal career management at the private level even though there is significant investment in the initial training of those members.' Any organisation, let alone the Australian Defence Force, where there is a general belief amongst members that they have little influence over their career progression, is going to have problems with morale and staff retention.

It would appear that the Defence Reform Program has further exacerbated feelings of the inadequate career progression of officers and enlisted personnel of the Australian Defence Force. Interviews conducted by the Auditor-General revealed that:

quote.para: Army and Navy personnel often stated that civilians are taking many jobs and posting options that rightfully belonged to Defence members.

speech.para: It was further reported that:

quote.para: ... there is a common perception that the skills, experience and general capability of military personnel, and the ADF itself, are being eroded through the increasing use of civilian workers and that morale is being lowered.

speech.para: Clearly, Defence Force personnel either have lost, or are losing, faith in the Defence Reform Program. Many in the ADF are of the belief that the Defence Force reform package is only about `an increasing emphasis on efficiency' at the expense of their working conditions. The Auditor-General's report stated:

quote.para: ... members consider that many of the savings reported in Defence Reform have been made only because they work longer hours and make do with reduced resourcing levels.

speech.para: Indeed, Australian Defence Force personnel state that they believe the Department of Defence is indifferent to the effect that continuous change is having on them both personally and professionally. Combine these feelings with reports of poor housing conditions for single personnel, the stresses that changes in postings place on ADF families and what is perceived by Defence personnel as an overall decline in military ethos, and you see a picture of a work environment that is far from optimal.
The Auditor-General's report found that:

quote.para: Defence could manage retention more effectively if it had a better understanding of the views of its members.

speech.para: The report went on to state:

quote.para: Defence attitude surveys and the re-introduction of exit surveys are examples of Defence attempts to obtain the information it needs to manage retention better.

speech.para: The gathering of information to manage retention better is a fine and worthwhile exercise by Defence. But it will be useless information if there is not the will, both within the Defence Force and the government, to genuinely want to improve the lives of our serving men and women. There must be adequate resources to provide good quality housing for all Defence personnel. The government must look sympathetically at the effects that serial postings can have on Defence families. The government needs to look at and understand the effects that the Defence Reform Program has had on the lives, morale and careers of Australian Defence Force personnel. Adequate resources need to be given to Defence's career management agencies so that ADF personnel can feel as though they have at least some control over their careers.

As I have previously stated, we have an economic and strategic imperative to maintain the best possible retention rate for Australian Defence Force personnel but, more importantly, we have a moral imperative to do so. The men and women of the Australian Defence Force have volunteered to serve their country. This does not give us the right to take their service for granted. Indeed, it obligates all of us to provide them with the best possible working environment we can. Any less is a betrayal of their trust in us as their political leaders.

talk.start.para: —I recently experienced the ordeal of a criminal trial for criminal assault. I was acquitted. Some of the media said the jury took an hour to reach its decision. In fact, the judge instructed the jury to go off to lunch, and they returned their unanimous not guilty verdict immediately after lunch. I have had to experience 20 months of stress, considerable legal expense and an uncertain degree of damage to my reputation. For now, I wish simply to put some matters to do with my case on the record and to make a few observations about the process.

speech.para: I had pleaded not guilty to the charge of assault occasioning bodily harm. The charge stemmed from an incident that occurred 20 months earlier while I was walking my dog. It involved my little dog, Benji, a terrier-cross; Ms Wendy Arthur, now Marshall, and her great dane, Ebony Bear; and Mr Warren Marshall. Despite the fact that Mrs Marshall, Mr Marshall and I all gave evidence on oath that no-one saw a blow land on Mrs Marshall, she alleged that I deliberately struck her on the head after her dog, Ebony Bear, ran towards Benji. The facts of the matter are that her dog, Ebony Bear, ran towards and then attacked Benji; to defend Benji, I hit and kicked her dog. If Mrs Marshall was struck while this was happening, she was struck accidentally either by me or by her dog's face. While I regret that she may have been hurt in the melee, it was an accident. I abhor violence against women and, as I stated in court, at all times my actions were directed at her dog and stemmed from my heartfelt belief that Benji was being fatally attacked.

Given the enormous hardship that accompanies a criminal charge, a great deal of careful consideration ought to be entered into prior to proceeding with a prosecution. In my opinion, the charge I faced was without merit. The prosecution was costly to the taxpayer and costly and stressful to me, my family and my staff. I think it should never have proceeded. The Crown alleged that I deliberately hit Mrs Marshall. Mrs Marshall claimed to have felt a blow but not to have seen it. Mr Marshall, who was about 75 metres away, did not see a blow despite observing the whole incident. I certainly saw no such blow. The judge made this point in his instructions to the jury, and I quote:

quote.para: ... there's no witness who has come into court and who has said `I saw the accused's hand hit Mrs Marshall on the head.'

speech.para: All witnesses agreed that they saw me being assaulted by Mr Marshall. Not only did Mr and Mrs Marshall not see me strike Mrs Marshall; each delivered testimony that was highly inconsistent with the other. Mrs Marshall made the extraordinary allegation that, while she was standing with her huge dog, I walked up behind her and hit her for no reason. Mr Marshall's testimony painted a different, inconsistent and ridiculous picture.

I find it most distressing that such a tenuous allegation could give rise to a costly and stressful 20-month ordeal such as the one I endured. There is no evidence for suspicions voiced to me that improper motives played a part in the process, whether of a political, personal or financial nature, or whether from vindictiveness or official incompetence. That cannot be known. All I do know is that a very serious allegation was made on the basis of an assertion of a blow to which there was no witness.

Compounding the damage to myself and my family was the media treatment. The media coverage was not biased or malicious, but it did have an impact. I read, watched and heard the media repeat again and again the allegation that I had criminally assaulted a woman, an allegation which, because of the process of law, I could not defend in the media until the second last day of 20 months when I could finally present my side of the story in court. The media can only report what is before them, and for 20 months what was before them was an allegation. It was naturally of interest to them because of my profile as a politician, and because of the real—if remote—threat of the loss of my job and the loss of jobs of my staff.

I have analysed print media coverage of the charge process and trial. The charge was brought against me on 25 July 1998. Someone leaked the news to the media within a hour of the police charging me. From the clippings which I have kept—which is not all the media coverage and does not include radio and television—prior to the trial on 7 March 2000, at least 310 centimetres of copy was printed in various newspapers throughout Australia detailing the charge and allegations made by Mrs Marshall. Media coverage was national, periodic and coincided with various procedural court appearances. The allegation hit the headlines in August, September and December 1998, and then again in March, May, June and October 1999 and January 2000. During the same period, just 52 centimetres of copy was printed detailing the fact that I intended to plead not guilty and my short statement of defence against the allegations made by Mrs Marshall. The media imbalance was obvious and naturally distressing, although I should again stress the media had no choice—they had only the allegation to go on with. After 20 long months, the trial began. Some of the media sat in the courtroom and for three days—7, 8 and 9 March this year—listened to the prosecution and defence, and then reported to the Australian public that I had been found not guilty of the charge.

Now let us look again at the figures. The trial commenced on 7 March this year, and the media devoted 85 centimetres of copy to the prosecution—to the allegations made against me by Mr and Mrs Marshall. From 8 March, the story was different—it was new, fresh, it was my defence. So, over just two days, I secured about 229 centimetres of copy on my defence. And then nothing. The story was no longer a story. The fact that I had been found not guilty would not be slowly filtered out to the public again and again over a 20--month period. Indeed, if you happened to be on holidays from 8 to 10March, you would have missed my defence of the allegation, missed the extremely important fact—to me at least—that I had been found not guilty.

I think the media coverage of my charge and case was very fair, but in percentage terms about 78 per cent of all print media coverage regarding this incident occurred before my trial, before my case was presented. Even if it is an unintentional consequence of the justice process, the constant repetition of an allegation does have a bias against the defendant. It is indicative of the hurt to reputation that can accrue to the innocent, despite the publication of the not guilty verdict and other favourable publicity on other matters.

Why do I raise these issues? Firstly, to be sure that as well as the transcript of the trial—and the judge's summation is particularly illuminating—this Senate has available at least a brief report from me on my trial. Secondly, to illustrate the troubles that are visited on public figures if criminal charges and the resultant media coverage are pursued when a case is quite flimsy. Thirdly, to illustrate that it is in the process of justice and publicity before the resolution of a case that unfairness and harm can accrue. We need to pay more attention to process, and I will have more to say on that at a later date.

The cost and the possible damage to my reputation remain. On the positive side, my compassion and concern for disadvantaged people facing criminal proceedings has not faded. It has been re-inforced. It is sometimes said that you can judge a society by the way it treats those it has charged and the way it treats those it has convicted. The treatment of accused persons also says a great deal about a society, and I have considerable misgivings about the operation of our criminal justice system after this experience—obviously, with particular reference to Western Australia.

In closing, I would like to say that in this parliament a great range of genuine supporters from all sides emerged who were keen to ensure that I was viewed as normal during the course of these events. I am deeply grateful to all those who offered their support to me over the trial period and throughout the 20 months.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to speak about a relatively small country in Africa, one which I have visited on many occasions and one where the previous speaker, my colleague Senator Murray, has spent a great deal of his life. The country I speak of is Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe was taken over in a democratic sense—only in a sense—by the present incumbent, Mr Mugabe, in 1980. Zimbabwe is landlocked and lies between the countries of Mozambique to the east, Botswana to the south, and Zambia, formerly Northern Rhodesia, to the north.

speech.para: It is a particularly beautiful country in a lot of areas. In its most westerly extremity, it has one of the great, if not the greatest, outstanding natural features of the world—Victoria Falls. It is apt to note that that is one of the few names that survived after the 1980 takeover of the Smith government by Robert Mugabe. I have been to Victoria Falls, as I have been to a lot of Southern Africa, and it is indeed a wonderful country. In the south, the Limpopo River borders South Africa and Mozambique, and Zimbabwe has running through it the mighty Zambezi River, which is the source of the water for Victoria Falls.

However, Zimbabwe today is far from an ideal nation. It still has its beauty, but it has immense trouble. There is immense trouble for the 12 million-odd people that comprise Zimbabwe, 98 per cent of whom are African of Shona and Ndebele extraction. In recent times President Mugabe—76 years old and described through the media as a megalomaniac, as a despot and as someone bordering on evil, if not evil—has brought his country not just to its economic knees but has, in the most extraordinary manner, taken over 600 of the 1,400 or thereabouts producing farms owned by white Zimbabweans with no compensation. The method used was to beat drums and to chant outside the houses to intimidate the people inside their homes so much that the black African workers left the farms. Those farms are largely lying vacant and fallow today. They are not producing the necessary income for the bereft economy, and others will undoubtedly be taken over. The High Court found in Zimbabwe that the move by President Mugabe to do this without compensation was, in fact, illegal. But that did not stop this black despot. What he did was pass a law through his parliament that allowed him to do precisely that in defiance of the High Court of Zimbabwe. There are approximately 70,000 white Zimbabweans involved in the rural industries in Zimbabwe, and they are of course in great danger. Two innocent farmers have already been killed, many more have been injured and many more will be injured before this is resolved.

I might just dwell for a moment on what could have been in Zimbabwe, a country that is rich in nickel, gold, silver, platinum, diamonds and copper. It has vast amounts of fresh water. It has vast hydro potential for cheap electricity. Yet only 10 per cent of those people in Zimbabwe are employed in rural industries. President Mugabe last year and the year before sent an army off to the Congo to support President Laurent Kabila at vast cost to the Zimbabwean economy—or to what remained of it. The economy is suffering to the tune of 70 per cent inflation now. Fifty per cent of the people in Zimbabwe are unemployed. In 1980, when President Mugabe took over this jewel of colonial Africa, formerly Southern Rhodesia, the exchange rate between the Zimbabwean dollar and the British pound was 50p. Today, that has dropped not to 25p or to 10p but to 1.5p. Literacy has dropped from 59 per cent in 1980 to 42 per cent today. Today, life expectancy for the total population is 38.86 years. It is 38.77 for males and 38.94 for females. The infant mortality rate is 61.21 deaths per 1,000 live births. Those are not figures that one would expect from a country that was left in excellent order by the former Premier of Southern Rhodesia, Mr Ian Smith.

Those farmers that have been displaced—20,000 of those 70,000 that are in danger—are to be replaced and relocated as a result of an offer from the United Kingdom. I would like to think that my government, my Australia, would also make some offer to bring these people who are in grave danger to the safety of Australia, as we have done with many people over the years, particularly in the last half a century or so, remembering that Australia is a nation of migrants. If we did that we would save them from this, as he has been described, `evil black tyrant'. His invasion of the farms is suicidal in a political and economic sense. Whatever Mr Mugabe does there, he is not going to resolve his problem by allowing veterans of his 1970s war of independence, his liberation war, to take over these farms in a manner that is contrary to the law, and contrary to the law of Zimbabwe in particular.

He has, in effect, single-handedly destroyed what was one of the brightest prospects in Africa. Mining is practically non-existent now, notwithstanding the riches of Zimbabwe. The rural industry has declined to the degree where some food items are being imported. Yet this man sends thousands of troops to what was formerly the Congo to defend Laurent Kabila's regime in that central African country. It seems preposterous when people are starving, when the economy is one of the worst in southern Africa, when the country cannot feed itself, when exports have dried up and when it has become a mendicant state of southern Africa that is dependent upon the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and other charitable organisations. It is unfair not just to those very friendly and affable people of Zimbabwe but particularly to those white Zimbabweans who stayed there and considered themselves nothing other than Zimbabwean. I do feel immense sorrow for and empathy with the white Zimbabweans in particular, but it is not confined to them alone. This government has the capacity to do something to alleviate that situation and I hope that it acts soon. (Time expired)

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) If a GST registered person dies and their business is carried on by the deceased estate until the assets can be sold, GST will apply to the sales of the various business assets in the same way as if the person were still alive.

(2) If the will provides for business assets to be divided among beneficiaries, the supply of those business assets will not be in the course or furtherance of the enterprise and no GST will be payable on the supply.

However, where the extent of creditable purpose has changed (because the assets are now used for a private rather than a creditable purpose), an adjustment may be required because the deceased estate is no longer entitled to full input tax credits on the acquisition of the business asset.

quote.para: (1) What contracts has the department, or any agency of the department, provided to the firm Arthur Andersen in the 1998-99 financial year.

(2) In each instance: (a) what was the purpose of the work undertaken by Arthur Andersen: (b) what has been the cost to the department of the contract: and (c) what selection process was used to select Arthur Andersen (open tender, short-list or some other process).

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: Preface: Where answers relate to contracts for consultancies, these details are publicly available in the FaCS and/or Centrelink Annual Reports for 1998-99 and appropriate references have been provided. Where answers relate to `non-consultancy' contracts, full details have been provided as these do not appear in the Annual Reports.

(1) 1 contract was provided to Arthur Andersen in 1998-99 by the Department of Family and Community Services (FaCS). No contracts were provided to Arthur Andersen by Centrelink or the Social Security Appeals Tribunal (SSAT).
(2) (a) Consultancy services for the purpose of the development of draft indicators that are consistent with and support the FaCS key objectives set out in the Department's Strategic Plan.
(b) Nil in FY 98/99
(c) Restricted tender.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 9 March 2000:

quote.para: (1) Can details be provided of the process being used to manage plutonium waste at Maralinga and, in particular: (a) does that process include in situ vitrification; (b) was the material disposed of in trenches; (c) what was the depth of cover of those trenches; and (d) can details be provided of the engineering specifications for the trenches, including lining and the ingress of moisture.
(2) How does the Maralinga plutonium disposal system compare with: (a) world's best practice; and (b) that proposed for uranium waste in South Australia.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator Minchin
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Both in situ vitrification and burial of debris have been used to treat contamination at Maralinga. The remediation methods were approved by the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA), the regulator to the Project.
(a) In situ vitrification was used to treat contaminated debris in 11 pits.
(b) Contaminated debris has also been disposed of in trenches and covered with clean soil.
(c) The following table gives detail of the depth of cover of clean cover soil over the top-most level of contaminated debris in each of the Maralinga trenches:

entry.para: Depth below natural surface of the top of contaminated soil/debris (m)
Height of `clean' soil mound over trench(m)
Total cover of `clean' soil over contaminated soil/debris(m)

quote.para: (d) The trenches are constructed to depths of 10-15 metres in bedrock, and, in all cases, the water table is at least 10-20 metres below the base of the trenches. The trenches are covered with clean soil, which is mounded from 0.6 to 3.0 metres above grade to facilitate water run-off. Marker layers of plastic have been placed above the contaminated debris in the Taranaki debris trench. The trenches are unlined.
The contaminated debris has been placed in trenches in a stable geological environment which is unlikely to experience erosion.
The integrity of the trenches will be routinely inspected under the long-term stewardship management plan for the site.

There has been no evidence of plutonium dissolving in the groundwater and moving since the time of the testing at Maralinga. The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation undertook solubility studies on plutonium in the Maralinga environment and the results showed that the plutonium had a very low solubility. This indicates that there is very little risk of plutonium leaching into the groundwater. In any event, the groundwater at Maralinga is very salty and is not suitable for consumption by humans or animals. There is no deep, fresh water source in or nearby Maralinga, so water from the area will not travel to regions where water from the water table is consumed.

(2) At Maralinga, the circumstances giving rise to the likelihood of radiation exposure, were already in place when decisions about the control of those risks were made. Remedial work was carried out to reduce an existing risk. According to the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), the Maralinga clean-up is an `intervention'. It is, therefore, incorrect to use the term `disposal' in relation to the treatment of the contaminated material at Maralinga. Using IAEA terminology, radioactive waste `disposal' situations are `practices' in that radiation exposures and their likelihood can be restricted from the start.

(a) The Maralinga Rehabilitation Project has been undertaken consistent with International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) requirements for `interventions' outlined in the 1996 publication International Basic Safety Standards for the Protection Against Ionising Radiation and for the Safety of Radiation Sources, Safety Series 155.

(b) Comparisons cannot usefully be made between the requirements of an `intervention' (Maralinga) and a `practice'(waste management). If the question concerning waste disposal “proposed for uranium waste in South Australia” refers to the national radioactive waste repository, it should be noted that the repository is not being established for the management of uranium waste, but for the disposal of waste arising from Australia's use of radioactive materials in medicine, research and industry. Uranium mine tailings are managed at the relevant mine site.
